Catalin Badea Université de Lille, CNRS, UMR 8524 - Laboratoire Paul Painlevé, 59000 Lille, France catalin.badea@univ-lille1.fr    Sophie Grivaux CNRS, Laboratoire Amiénois de Mathématique Fondamentale et Appliquée, UMR 7352, Université de Picardie Jules Verne, 33 rue Saint-Leu, 80039 Amiens Cedex 1, France sophie.grivaux@u-picardie.fr
November 30, 2018
Abstract

We study Kazhdan sets in topological groups which do not necessarily have Property (T). We provide a new criterion for a subset Q of a group G which generates G to be a Kazhdan set; it relies on the existence of a positive number ε such that every unitary representation of G with a (Q,ε)-invariant vector has a finite dimensional subrepresentation. Using this result, we give an equidistribution criterion for a subset of G which generates G to be a Kazhdan set. In the case where G=ℤ, this shows that if (nk)k≥1 is a sequence of integers such that (e2⁢i⁢π⁢θ⁢nk)k≥1 is uniformly distributed in the unit circle for all real numbers θ except at most countably many, {nk;k≥1} is a Kazhdan set in ℤ as soon as it generates ℤ. This answers a question of Y. Shalom. We also obtain a complete characterization of Kazhdan sets in second countable locally compact abelian groups, in the Heisenberg groups, the a⁢x+b group, and S⁢L2⁢(ℝ). This answers in particular a question from [B. Bekka, P. de la Harpe, A. Valette, Kazhdan’s property (T), Cambridge Univ. Press, 2008]. Lastly, we provide some further applications of Kazhdan sets: we generalize a local rigidity result of Rapinchuk, and give a characterization of Kazhdan sets in terms of strong ergodicity of groups actions; this last result is related to a characterization of Property (T) due to Connes and Weiss.

Kazhdan sets, topological groups, Property (T), equidistributed sequences in groups, tensor products of unitary representations, weakly mixing representations, compact unitary representations, abstract Wiener theorem, Heisenberg groups, a⁢x+b group, Howe-Moore property, locally rigid representations, strongly ergodic group actions.

1 Introduction

Property (T) is a rigidity property of topological groups which has been introduced by Kazhdan in [35] for locally compact groups, and which has spectacular applications to many fields, such as the study of discrete subgroups of Lie groups, ergodic theory, operators algebras, random walks, explicit constructions of expander graphs and generation of (nearly) uniformly distributed random elements in groups. We refer the reader to the monograph [7] by Bekka, de la Harpe, and Valette for a comprehensive presentation of Kazhdan’s Property (T) and its applications (see also [27]). Among amenable locally compact groups, the only ones which have Property (T) are the compact ones. If K is a local field and n≥2 is an integer, the groups S⁢Ln⁢(K) have Property (T) if and only if n≥3. A lattice Γ in a locally compact group G has Property (T) if and only if G has it, so that for instance the groups S⁢Ln⁢(ℤ) have Property (T) for n≥3. The group S⁢L2⁢(ℤ) does not have Property (T).

Property (T) can be defined as the existence of a Kazhdan pair consisting of a compact Kazhdan set and its corresponding Kazhdan constant (the precise definitions will be given in Section 2 below). Locally compact groups with Property (T) are compactly generated. In particular, discrete groups with Property (T) are finitely generated and it is known (see [7, Prop. 1.3.2]) that the Kazhdan subsets of a discrete group with Property (T) are exactly the generating subsets of the group. More generally [7, Prop. 1.3.2], a generating set of a locally compact group which has Property (T) is a Kazhdan set and, conversely, a Kazhdan set which has non-empty interior is necessarily a generating set. However, the determination of explicit Kazhdan pairs in a group with Property (T) is usually a difficult task. This natural problem of identifying Kazhdan pairs has been raised by Serre and by de la Harpe and Valette (see [12] and [27, p. 133]). Besides these references, we refer the reader to [7, Ch. 4], which presents a method of Shalom [51] for obtaining Kazhdan pairs for such groups as S⁢Ln⁢(ℤ), n≥3, [31] which gives the exact asymptotic behaviour, as n goes to infinity, n≥3, of the Kazhdan constant of the Kazhdan subset of S⁢Ln⁢(ℤ) consisting of the elementary matrices, [56] where Kazhdan constants are obtained for certain discrete groups given by presentations, and [5] where it is proved that the unitary group 𝒰⁢(H) of a separable infinite dimensional Hilbert space H, equipped with the strong operator topology, has Property (T), and where explicit finite Kazhdan sets in 𝒰⁢(H) are given (in this last example, the group is not locally compact). Notice also that while is not difficult to show that compact groups have Property (T), the computation of Kazhdan constants is nontrivial even for this class of groups; see for instance [44] and the references therein.

Even if a topological group does not have Property (T) it is still interesting to investigate some natural weaker rigidity properties of the group. See for example [40], or [39] which introduces the weaker Property (τ). Property (τ) is for instance sufficient for applications to expander graphs. It is also an interesting and difficult problem, mentioned in [7, Sec. 7.12] to exhibit “small” Kazhdan subsets of groups which do not have Property (T) and, more generally, to determine the class of all Kazhdan subsets of such groups.

The main motivations for the present paper are the following two questions of [7, Sec. 7.12]. The first one is due to Y. Shalom:

Question 1.1

[7, Sec. 7.12] “The question of knowing if a subset Q of Z is a Kazhdan set is possibly related to the equidistribution of the sequence (e2⁢i⁢π⁢n⁢θ)n∈Q for θ irrational, in the sense of Weyl.”

It is not difficult to see that if p≥2, p⁢ℤ is not a Kazhdan set in ℤ, while the sequence (e2⁢i⁢π⁢p⁢n⁢θ)n∈ℤ is uniformly distributed in the circle 𝕋 for every irrational number θ. Also, the set {2k+k;k≥1} is a Kazhdan set in ℤ, while there are irrational numbers θ such that (e2⁢i⁢π⁢(2k+k)⁢θ)k≥1 is not equidistributed in 𝕋 (see Example 7.2 and Remark 7.3 below). So Question 1.1 may be rephrased as follows:

Question 1.2

Let Q={nk;k≥1} be a subset of Z such that the subgroup of Z generated by Q is equal to Z. Suppose that the sequence (e2⁢i⁢π⁢nk⁢θ)k≥1 is uniformly distributed in T for every irrational number θ. Is Q a Kazhdan set in Z?

The second question of [7, Sec. 7.12] runs as follows:

Question 1.3

[7, Sec. 7.12] “More generally, what are the Kazhdan subsets of Zk, Rk, the Heisenberg group, or other infinite amenable groups?”

There are several possible ways of defining uniformly distributed sequences in ℤ and, more generally, in locally compact groups. We refer the reader to the books [37] and [18], and to the papers by Veech [53], [54] and Losert and Rindler [38], [25] for a presentation of various notions of uniform distribution in general locally compact groups. If (gk)k≥1 is a sequence of elements in a locally compact group G, uniform distribution of (gk)k≥1 in any of these senses requires a certain form of convergence, as N tends to infinity, of the means

1N⁢∑k=1Nπ⁢(gk) (1)

to the orthogonal projection Pπ on the subspace of invariant vectors for π, for a certain class of unitary representations π of G. Veech [53], [54] calls (gk)k≥1 uniformly distributed in G if the convergence of the means (1) holds in the weak operator topology for all unitary representations of G (or, equivalently, for all irreducible unitary representations of G, provided G is supposed to be second countable). Unitary uniform distribution in the sense of Losert and Rindler [38], [25] requires the convergence in the strong operator topology of the means (1) for all irreducible unitary representations of the group, while Hartman uniform distribution only requires convergence in the strong operator topology for all finite dimensional unitary representations. All these notions coincide when G is a Moore group, i.e. when all irreducible unitary representations of the group are finite dimensional. It is essentially obvious that if (gk)k≥1 is a sequence of elements of a locally compact group G which is uniformly distributed in G in any of these senses, the set {gk;k≥1} is a Kazhdan set in G.

In the case of the group ℤ, the classic Weyl criterion [37] implies that a sequence (nk)k≥1 of elements of ℤ is unitarily or Hartman uniformly distributed in ℤ if and only if the sequence (e2⁢i⁢π⁢nk⁢θ)k≥1 is uniformly distributed in 𝕋 for every θ∈ℝ∖ℤ, where 𝕋 denotes as usual the unit circle in ℂ. As observed just above, it is in this case straightforward to show that {nk;k≥1} is a Kazhdan set in ℤ. Now, it is in many settings much more convenient and natural to consider the weaker equidistribution condition that (e2⁢i⁢π⁢θ⁢nk)k≥1 is uniformly distributed in 𝕋 for every θ∈ℝ∖ℚ: this is the condition which appears in Shalom’s Question 1.1. It is of course a weaker requirement on (nk)k≥1 than that of being Hartman uniformly distributed, and the sequence (nk)k≥1 given by nk=k2 verifies the equidistribution condition of Question 1.1 although it is not Hartman uniformly distributed in ℤ.

We will consider in this paper a natural extension to general locally compact groups G of the equidistribution condition of Question 1.1: if (gk)k≥1 is a sequence of elements of G, we require the means (1) to converge for all finite dimensional unitary representations of G except at most countably many. In the case of the group ℤ, sequences (nk)k≥1 of integers such that (e2⁢i⁢π⁢θ⁢nk)k≥1 is uniformly distributed in 𝕋 for all θ∈ℝ except countably many are said to be of first kind (see for instance [29]). The generalization of Question 1.2 to this setting runs as follows:

Question 1.4

Let (gk)k≥1 be a sequence of elements of a locally compact group G which satisfies the following equidistribution property:

for all finite dimensional irreducible unitary representations π of G on a Hilbert space H, except at most countably many, \xymatrix⁢@⁢C=50⁢p⁢t⁢1N⁢∑k=1N⟨π⁢(gk)⁢x,y⟩⁢\ar⁢[r]-⁢\xymatrix⁢@C=13ptN\ar[r]&+⁢∞⁢&⁢0 for every⁢x,y∈H. (2)

When is it true that Q={gk;k≥1} is a Kazhdan set in G?

We provide in this work an answer to Question 1.4 when G is a second countable Moore group, and thus fully answer Shalom’s Question 1.1 as well. We also answer Question 1.3 by giving a complete description of Kazhdan sets in many classic groups which do not have Property (T), including the groups ℤk and ℝk, k≥1, and the Heisenberg groups of all dimensions. Let us now describe our main results in more detail.

2 Main results

We first briefly set down some notation and recall some important definitions.

2.1 Definitions and notation

The Hilbert spaces will always be supposed in this paper to be complex, and endowed with an inner product ⟨⋅,⋅⟩ which is linear in the first variable and antilinear in the second variable. A unitary representation of G on H is a group morphism from G into the group 𝒰⁢(H) of all unitary operators on H which is strongly continuous, i. e. such that the map \xymatrix⁢g⁢\ar⁢@⁢|->⁢[r]⁢&⁢π⁢(g)⁢x is continuous from G into H for all vectors x∈H. As all the representations we consider in this paper are unitary, we will often drop the word “unitary” and speak simply of representations of a group G on a Hilbert space H.

Definition 2.1

Let Q be a subset of a topological group G, ε a positive real number, and π a unitary representation of G on a Hilbert space H. A vector x∈H is said to be (Q,ε)-invariant for π if

supg∈Q⁡||π⁢(g)⁢x-x||<ε⁢||x||.

A (Q,ε)-invariant vector for π is in particular non-zero. A G-invariant vector for π is a vector x∈H such that π⁢(g)⁢x=x for all g∈G.

The notions of Kazhdan sets and Kazhdan pairs will be fundamental in our work.

Definition 2.2

A subset Q of a topological group G is a Kazhdan set in G if there exists ε>0 such that the following property holds true: any unitary representation π of G on a complex Hilbert space H with a (Q,ε)-invariant vector has a non-zero G-invariant vector. In this case, the pair (Q,ε) is Kazhdan pair, and ε is a Kazhdan constant for Q. A group G has Property (T), or is a Kazhdan group, if it admits a compact Kazhdan set.

Lastly, we introduce a generating property of a subset of a group, which is weaker that the notion of generating set as used for instance in [7].

Definition 2.3

If Q is any subset of a group G, we denote by ⟨Q⟩ the smallest subgroup of G containing Q, i. e. the set of all elements of the form g1±1⁢…⁢gn±1, where n≥1 and g1,…,gn belong to Q. We say that Q generates G if ⟨Q⟩=G. It is equivalent to requiring that Q~=Q∪Q-1 be a generating set in the sense of [7, Sec. 7.1].

2.2 Equidistributed sets in Moore groups

Our first main result provides a complete answer to Question 1.4 when the group G is a second countable Moore group, i. e. when all irreducible representations of G are finite dimensional. Locally compact Moore groups are completely described in [43]: a Lie group is a Moore group if and only if it has a closed subgroup H such that H modulo its center is compact, and a locally compact group is a Moore group if and only if it is a projective limit of Lie groups which are Moore groups. See also the survey [46] for more information concerning the links between various properties of topological groups, among them the property of being a Moore group. Of course all locally compact abelian groups are Moore groups.

Theorem 2.4

Let G be a second countable locally compact Moore group. Let Q be a subset of G of the form Q={gk;k≥1} where (gk)k≥1 is a sequence of elements of G. Suppose that Q generates G, and that (gk)k≥1 satisfies the following assumption:

for all (finite dimensional) irreducible unitary representations π of G on a Hilbert space H, except at most countably many, \xymatrix⁢@⁢C=50⁢p⁢t⁢1N⁢∑k=1N⟨π⁢(gk)⁢x,y⟩⁢\ar⁢[r]-⁢\xymatrix⁢@C=13ptN\ar[r]&+⁢∞⁢&⁢0 for every⁢x,y∈H. (3)

Then Q is a Kazhdan set in G.

As explained in the introduction, property (3) above is an equidistribution property of the sequence (gk)k≥1. It takes a more familiar form when the group G is supposed to be abelian: it is equivalent to requiring that condition (4) below holds true for all characters χ of the group except possibly countably many.

Theorem 2.5

Let G be a locally compact abelian group, and let (gk)k≥1 be a sequence of elements of G. Suppose that Q={gk;k≥1} generates G, and that

\xymatrix⁢@⁢C=50⁢p⁢t⁢1N⁢∑k=1Nχ⁢(gk)⁢\ar⁢[r]-⁢\xymatrix⁢@C=13pt𝑁\ar[r]&+⁢∞⁢&⁢0 (4)

for all characters χ on G, except at most countably many. Then Q is a Kazhdan set in G.

Theorem 2.5 can thus be seen as a particular case of Theorem 2.4, except for the fact that there is no need to suppose that the group is second countable when it is known to be abelian. Specializing Theorem 2.5 to the case where G=ℤ, we obtain the following complete answer to Question 1.2 above:

Theorem 2.6

Let (nk)k≥1 be a sequence of elements of Z, and set Q={nk;k≥1}. Suppose that the sequence (e2⁢i⁢π⁢nk⁢θ)k≥1 is equidistributed in the unit circle T for all real numbers θ except at most countably many. The following assertions are equivalent:

  1. (a)

    Q is a Kazhdan set in ℤ;

  2. (b)

    Q generates ℤ.

2.3 Kazhdan sets and finite dimensional subrepresentations

The proof of Theorem 2.5 relies on Theorem 2.7 below, which gives a new condition for a “small perturbation” of a subset Q of a group G to be a Kazhdan set in G. Theorem 2.7 constitutes the core of the paper, and has, besides the proofs of Theorems 2.4, 2.5, and 2.6, several interesting applications which we will present in Sections 7 and 8.

Theorem 2.7

Let G be a topological group, and let (Wn)n≥1 be an increasing sequence of subsets of G such that W1 is a neighborhood of the unit element e of G and ⋃\gnW=nG. Let Q be a subset of G satisfying the following assumption:

there exists a positive constant ε such that every unitary representation π of G on a Hilbert space H admitting a ( Q , ε ) -invariant vector has a finite dimensional subrepresentation. (*)

Then there exists an integer n≥1 such that Qn=Wn∪Q is a Kazhdan set in G.

If the group G is locally compact, the same statement holds true for any increasing sequence (Wn)n≥1 of subsets of G such that ⋃\gnW=nG (we no longer need to request that W1 be a neighborhood of e).

If the group G is locally compact and σ-compact, we can choose for (Wn)n≥1 an increasing sequence of compact sets whose union is equal to G. If Q is a subset of G satisfying (* ‣ 2.7), there exists then by Theorem 2.7 a compact subset L of G such that L∪Q is a Kazhdan set in G. We thus retrieve a characterization of Property (T) for σ-compact locally compact groups due to Bekka and Valette [6], see also [7, Th. 2.12.9]. The original proof of this result relies on the Delorme-Guichardet theorem that such a group has Property (T) if and only if it has property (FH), that is every affine isometric action of G on a real Hilbert space has a fixed point. See Section 6 for more details.

Theorem 2.7 admits a simpler formulation if we build the sequence (Wn)n≥1 starting from a set which generates the group in the sense of Definition 2.3:

Corollary 2.8

Let G be a topological group. Let Q0 be a subset of G which generates G and has non-empty interior, and Q a subset of G. If Q satisfies assumption (* ‣ 2.7) of Theorem 2.7, Q0∪Q is a Kazhdan set in G.

If G is a locally compact group, it suffices to assume that Q0 generates G in order to obtain the same conclusion.

One of the main consequences of Corollary 2.8 is Theorem 2.9 below, which shows in particular that property (* ‣ 2.7) of Theorem 2.7 characterizes Kazhdan sets among sets which generate the group (and have non-empty interior – this assumption has to be added if the group is not supposed to be locally compact).

Theorem 2.9

Let G be a topological group and let Q be a subset of G which generates G and has non-empty interior. Then the following assertions are equivalent:

  1. (a)

    Q is a Kazhdan set in G;

  2. (b)

    there exists a constant δ∈(0,1) such that every unitary representation π of G on a Hilbert space H admitting a vector x∈H such that infg∈Q⁡|⟨π⁢(g)⁢x,x⟩|>δ⁢∥x∥2 has a finite dimensional subrepresentation;

  3. (c)

    there exists a positive constant ε such that every unitary representation π of G on a Hilbert space H admitting a (Q,ε)-invariant vector has a finite dimensional subrepresentation.

If the group G is locally compact and Q generates G, assertions (a), (b) and (c) above are equivalent.

Condition (b) in Theorem 2.9 is easily seen to be equivalent to condition (c), which is nothing else than assumption (* ‣ 2.7) of Theorem 2.7. Its interest will become clearer in Section 7 below, where it will be used to obtain a characterization of Kazhdan sets in second countable locally compact abelian groups.

The assumption that Q generates G cannot be dispensed with in Theorem 2.9: Q=2⁢ℤ is a subset of ℤ which satisfies property (c), but Q is clearly not a Kazhdan set in ℤ, while {1}∪Q is one. Indeed, if G is a discrete group, a Kazhdan subset Q of G must necessarily generate G (see [7, Prop. 1.3.2]). Hence Theorem 2.9 can be reformulated in the case of discrete groups so as to give a complete characterization of Kazhdan sets in G in terms of assumption (* ‣ 2.7) of Theorem 2.7:

Theorem 2.10

Let G be a discrete group, and let Q be a subset of G. The following assertions are equivalent:

  1. (a)

    Q is a Kazhdan set in G;

  2. (b)

    Q generates G, and there exists a constant δ∈(0,1) such that every unitary representation π of G on a Hilbert space H for which there exists a vector x∈H such that infg∈Q⁡|⟨π⁢(g)⁢x,x⟩|>δ⁢∥x∥2 has a finite dimensional subrepresentation;

  3. (c)

    Q generates G, and there exists a positive constant ε such that every unitary representation π of G on a Hilbert space H admitting a (Q,ε)-invariant vector has a finite dimensional subrepresentation.

2.4 Examples and applications

We characterize Kazhdan sets in various groups in which irreducible unitary representations are completely described. Using the new criterion provided by Theorem 2.9, we first provide such a characterization of Kazhdan sets in second countable locally compact abelian groups (Theorem 7.4). In the case of the group ℤ, the characterization we obtain (Theorem 7.6) involves a classic class of sets in hamonic analysis, called Kaufman sets. We also present some examples of Kazhdan sets in this setting. We then describe Kazhdan sets in the Heisenberg groups Hn, n≥1 (Theorem 7.12) and in the a⁢x+b group (Theorem 7.15). We finally study Kazhdan sets in groups with the Howe-Moore property, and obtain a complete characterization of Kazhdan sets in groups with the Howe-Moore property but without Property (T) (Theorem 7.17), which yields a description of Kazhdan sets in S⁢L2⁢(ℝ). See Section 7 for detailed statements of these results, which provide an answer to Question 1.3.

We also obtain two further applications of Kazhdan sets. The first one (Theorem 8.1) is a generalization of a result of Rapinchuk [49] concerning the local rigidity of finite dimensional unitary representations in discrete groups with Property (T). The second application (Theorem 8.3) consists in a version for Kazhdan sets of a characterization of Property (T) due to Connes and Weiss [16]. Namely, we prove that if Q is a subset of a topological group G which generates G, it is a Kazhdan set in G if and only if every weakly mixing action of G on a probability space is Q-strongly ergodic (see Section 8.2 for definitions). These applications highlight one more time the importance of determining Kazhdan sets in general groups.

2.5 Organization of the paper

The first half of the paper is devoted to the proof of Theorem 2.9. Section 3 is mostly expository, and presents some essential results and tools concerning ergodic theory for unitary representations of arbitrary topological groups. Section 4 is devoted to the proof of an abstract version of the Wiener Theorem (Theorem 4.7): if π is any unitary representation of a topological group G on a Hilbert space H, Theorem 4.7 provides an explicit expression for the quantities mG⁢(|⟨π⁢(∙)⁢x,y⟩|2), x,y∈H, where mG is the unique invariant mean on WAP(G). This theorem is crucial for the proof of Theorem 2.7, which proceeds by contradiction: we use Theorem 4.7 to show that certain infinite tensor products of finite dimensional representations are weakly mixing. The proof of Theorem 2.7 is given in Section 5. The equidistribution criteria for Kazhdan sets (Theorems 2.4, 2.5 and 2.6) are proved in Section 6, as well as Corollary 2.8, Theorem 2.9 and Corollary 2.10. Section 7 is devoted to examples; the characterizations of Kazhdan sets in second countable locally compact abelian groups, and in ℤ in particular, in the Heisenberg groups, the a⁢x+b group, and groups with the Howe-Moore property are proved in Theorems 7.4, 7.6, 7.12, 7.15 and 7.17 respectively. The extensions of the Rapinchuk rigidity result [49] and of the Connes-Weiss characterization of Property (T) [16] are proved in Section 8. The paper also contains an appendix which reviews some constructions of infinite tensor products of Hilbert spaces and of unitary representations, which are used in the proof of Theorem 2.7.

3 Ergodic theory and mixing properties for unitary representations of topological groups

The proof of our main theorem will require a rather precise knowledge of the structure of unitary representations of a topological group G. We first recall in this section some definitions and results that we will need. They can be found for instance in the forthcoming book [36], the notes [47], and the paper [9] by Bergelson and Rosenblatt.

Let π be a unitary representation of G on a complex Hilbert space H. In the case where G=ℤ, the well-known (weak) ergodic theorem of von Neumann states that if U is a unitary operator on H,

\xymatrix⁢1N⁢∑n=1N⟨Un⁢x,y⟩⁢\ar⁢[r]⁢&⁢⟨P⁢x,y⟩

as N tends to infinity for every vectors x,y∈H, where P denotes the orthogonal projection in H onto the subspace ker⁡(U-I) of fixed points of U. This result admits an extension to amenable groups (see [17] or [19]) and, by using the existence of an invariant mean on weakly almost periodic functions on G, to all topological groups. Recall that the class WAP(G) of weakly almost periodic functions on G is defined as follows: if ℓ∞⁢(G) denotes the space of bounded functions on G, f∈ℓ∞⁢(G) belongs to WAP(G) if the weak closure in ℓ∞⁢(G) of the set {f(s-1∙);s∈G} is weakly compact. For each s∈G, f(s-1∙) denotes the function \xymatrix⁢t⁢\ar⁢@⁢|->⁢[r]⁢&⁢f⁢(s-1⁢t) on G. By comparison, recall that f∈ℓ∞⁢(G) is an almost periodic function on G, written f∈AP(G), if the norm closure in ℓ∞⁢(G) of {f(s-1∙);s∈G} is compact. If π is a unitary representation of G on a Hilbert space H, the functions

⟨π⁢(∙)⁢x,y⟩,|⟨π⁢(∙)⁢x,y⟩|,and |⟨π⁢(∙)⁢x,y⟩|2,

where x and y are any vectors of H, belong to WAP(G). For more on weakly almost periodic functions on a group, see for instance [11] or [24, Ch. 1, Sec. 9]. The interest of the class of weakly almost periodic functions on G in our context is that there exists on WAP(G) a unique G-invariant mean m. It satisfies

m(f(s-1∙))=m(f(∙s-1))=m(f)

for every f∈WAP(G) and every s∈G. The abstract ergodic theorem then states that if π is a unitary representation of G on H,

m⁢(⟨π⁢(∙)⁢x,y⟩)=⟨Pπ⁢x,y⟩

for every vectors x,y∈H, where Pπ denotes the projection of H onto the space

Eπ={x∈H;π(g)x=x for everyg∈G}

of G-invariant vectors for π. The representation π is ergodic (i. e. admits no non-zero G-invariant vector) if and only if m⁢(⟨π⁢(∙)⁢x,y⟩)=0 for every x,y∈H.

Following [9], let us now recall that the representation π is said to be weakly mixing if m⁢(|⟨π⁢(∙)⁢x,x⟩|)=0 for every x∈H, or, equivalently, m⁢(|⟨π⁢(∙)⁢x,x⟩|2)=0 for every x∈H. Then m⁢(|⟨π⁢(∙)⁢x,y⟩|)=m⁢(|⟨π⁢(∙)⁢x,y⟩|2)=0 for every x,y∈H.

There are several important characterizations of weak mixing for unitary representations, one of which involves the adjoint representation π¯ of a unitary representation π of G on H. It is a representation of G on the adjoint Hilbert space H¯: H¯ coincides with H as a set, and its elements are denoted by x¯, where x∈H. The multiplication by a scalar λ on H¯ is defined by λ⁢x¯=λ¯⁢x¯ for every x¯∈H¯, and the scalar product of two elements x¯ and y¯ of H¯ is given by ⟨x¯,y¯⟩=⟨x,y⟩¯. Then the representation π¯ of G on H¯ is defined by setting π¯⁢(g)⁢x¯=π⁢(g)⁢x¯ for every g∈G and every x¯∈H¯.

Weak mixing for unitary representations is characterized by the fact that the tensor product representation π⊗π¯ of G on H⊗H¯ is ergodic, i. e. admits no non-zero G-invariant vector. This relies on the observation that for any vectors x,y∈H,

m⁢(⟨π⊗π¯⁢(∙)⁢x⊗x¯,y⊗y¯⟩)=m⁢(|⟨π⁢(∙)⁢x,y⟩|2).

The ergodic theorem applied to the representation π⊗π¯ and to the vectors x⊗x¯ and y⊗y¯ thus yields that

m⁢(|⟨π⁢(∙)⁢x,y⟩|2)=⟨Pπ⊗π¯⁢x⊗x¯,y⊗y¯⟩. (5)

The representation π⊗π¯ is equivalent to a representation of G on the space H⁢S⁢(H) of Hilbert-Schmidt operators on H, which is often more convenient to work with. Recall that H⁢S⁢(H) is a Hilbert space when endowed with the scalar product defined by the formula ⟨A,B⟩=tr⁢(B*⁢A) for every A,B∈H⁢S⁢(H). The space H⊗H¯ is identified to H⁢S⁢(H) by associating to each elementary tensor product x⊗y¯ of H⊗H¯ the rank-one operator ⟨∙,y⟩⁢x on H. This map Θ:\xymatrix⁢H⊗H¯⁢\ar⁢[r]⁢&⁢H⁢S⁢(H) extends into a unitary isomorphism, and we have for every g∈G and every T∈H⁢S⁢(H)

Θ⁢π⊗π¯⁢(g)⁢Θ-1⁢(T)=π⁢(g)⁢T⁢π⁢(g-1).

We will, when needed, identify π⊗π¯ with this equivalent representation, and use it in particular in Section 4 to obtain a concrete description of the space Eπ⊗π¯ of G-invariant vectors for π⊗π¯, which is identified to the subspace of H⁢S⁢(H)

𝗘π={T∈HS(H);π(g)T=Tπ(g)for everyg∈G}⋅

Seeing π⊗π¯ as a representation of G on H⁢S⁢(H) also allows one to prove that π⊗π¯ has a non-zero G-invariant vector if and only if π admits a finite dimensional subrepresentation. We summarize this in the following proposition:

Proposition 3.1

Let π be a unitary representation of G on a Hilbert space H. The following assertions are equivalent:

  1. (1)

    π is weakly mixing;

  2. (2)

    π admits no finite dimensional subrepresentation;

  3. (3)

    π⊗π¯ has no non-zero G-invariant vector.

A companion to the property of weak mixing for unitary representation is that of compactness: given a unitary representation π of G on H a vector x∈H is compact for π if the norm closure of the set {π⁢(g)⁢x;g∈G} is compact in H. The representation π itself is said to be compact if every vector of H is compact for π. Compact representations decompose as direct sums of irreducible finite dimensional representations. A representation π is weakly mixing if and only if the only compact vector for π is the zero vector. The general structural result for unitary representations is given by Proposition 3.2. It extends a well-known result of Jacobs, de Leeuw and Glicksberg (see for instance [22] for an account of this result) which associates to any contraction T on a Hilbert space H a decomposition of H into two T- and T*-invariant subspaces of T. This two spaces correspond respectively to the weakly mixing and compact parts in the statement below.

Proposition 3.2

A unitary representation π of G on a Hilbert space H decomposes as a direct sum of a weakly mixing representation and a compact representation:

H=Hw⁢⊕⟂Hc,

where Hw and Hc are both G-invariant closed subspaces of H, πw=π|Hw is weakly mixing and πc=π|Hc is compact. Hence π decomposes as a direct sum of a weakly mixing representation and finite dimensional irreducible subrepresentations.

See [47, Ch. 1], [7, Appendix M], [9] or [19] (in the amenable case) for detailed proofs of these results.

4 An abstract version of the Wiener Theorem

4.1 Notation

Let π be a compact representation of G on a Hilbert space H. We have seen in Section 3 that π can be decomposed as a direct sum of irreducible finite dimensional representations of G. We sort out these representations by equivalence classes, and index the distinct equivalence classes by an index j belonging to a set J, which may be finite or infinite (and which is countable if H is separable). For every j∈J, we index by i∈Ij all the representations appearing in the decomposition of π which are in the j-th equivalence class. More precisely, we can decompose H and π as

H=⊕j∈J(⊕\iijH)i,j and π=⊕j∈J(⊕i∈Ijπ)i,j

respectively, where the following holds true:

  1. –

    for every j∈J the spaces Hi,j, i∈Ij, are equal. We denote by Kj this common space, and by dj its dimension (which is finite). We also write

    H~j=⊕\iijH,i,jso that H=⊕j∈JH~j;
  2. –

    for every j∈J, there exists an irreducible representation πj of G on Kj such that πi,j is equivalent to πj for every i∈Ij. We also denote by Ui,j a unitary operator from Hi,j into Kj such that π=i,jUπji,j*Ui,j;

  3. –

    if j, j′ belong to J and j≠j′, πj and πj′ are not equivalent.

If we denote by U the unitary operator ⊕j∈J(⊕\iijU)i,j from H=⊕j∈J(⊕\iijH)i,j into ⊕j∈J(⊕\iijK)j, we have π=U*⁢π′⁢U,where π′=⊕j∈J(⊕i∈Ijπj).

For every j∈J, we denote by P~j the orthogonal projection of H on H~j, and, for every i∈Ij, by Pi,j the orthogonal projection of H on Hi,j and by τi,j the canonical injection of Hi,j into H.

Let A∈ℬ⁢(H). For every k,l∈J, every u∈Ik, and every v∈Il, we denote by Au,v the operator from Hv,l into Hu,k defined by Au,v=Pu,k⁢A|Hv,l. Thus we can write A in block-matrix form with respect to the decomposition

H=⊕j∈J(⊕\iijH)i,j as A=(Au,v)k,l∈J,u∈Ik,v∈Il⋅

If we define, for k,l∈J, A~k,l=P~k⁢A|H~l, we can also write A in block-matrix form with respect to the decomposition

H=⊕j∈JH~j as A=(A~k,l)k,l∈J,

and of course A~k,l=(Au,v)u∈Ik,v∈Il for every k,l∈J.

4.2 A formula for the projection 𝗣π of H⁢S⁢(H) on 𝗘π.

Our first aim in this section is to give an explicit formula for the projection 𝗣π⁢A of a Hilbert-Schmidt operator A∈H⁢S⁢(H) on the closed subspace of H⁢S⁢(H)

𝗘π={T∈HS(H);π(g)T=Tπ(g)for everyg∈G}

and to compute the norm of 𝗣π⁢A.

Proposition 4.1

Let π be a compact representation of G on H, written in the form π=⊕j∈J(⊕i∈Ijπ)i,j as discussed in Section 4.1 above. For every Hilbert-Schmidt operator A on H, we have

𝙋π⁢A =∑j∈J1dj⁢∑u,v∈Ijtr⁢(Uv,j*⁢Uu,j⁢Au,v)⁢τu,j⁢Uu,j*⁢Uv,j⁢Pv,j.
Hence
||𝙋π⁢A||2 =∑j∈J1dj⁢∑u,v∈Ij|tr⁢(Uv,j*⁢Uu,j⁢Au,v)|2.
Remark 4.2

In the particular case where π has the form π=π′=⊕j∈J(⊕i∈Ijπj), i. e. when for every j∈J the representations πi,j, i∈Ij, are equal (and not only equivalent), the formula becomes

𝙋π⁢A=∑j∈J1dj⁢∑u,v∈Ij𝑡𝑟⁢(Au,v)⁢τu,j⁢iu,v⁢Pv,j

where iu,v is the identity operator from Hv,j into Hu,j.

Remark 4.3

If k,l∈J, u∈Ik, v∈Il, and Au,v is any bounded operator from Hv,l into Hu,k, the operator τu,k⁢Au,v⁢Pv,l is simply the canonical extension A′ of Au,v to the whole space H. Since Hv,l and Hu,k are finite dimensional, A′ is a Hilbert-Schmidt operator on H and ||A′||H⁢S=||Au,v||H⁢S. For any B∈H⁢S⁢(H), we have

⟨A′,B⟩=𝑡𝑟⁢(Bu,v*⁢Au,v)=⟨Au,v,Bu,v⟩,

the last notation being slightly abusive.

The proof of Proposition 4.1 relies on the following lemma, which gives a complete description of 𝗘π in terms of block-matrices.

Lemma 4.4

The space 𝗘π consists of the operators T∈HS⁢(H) such that

  1. –

    for every k,l∈J with k≠l, T~k,l=0;

  2. –

    for every k∈J and every u,v∈Ik, there exists a complex number λu,v such that Tu,v=λu,v⁢Uu,k*⁢Uv,k. Thus T~k,k=(λu,v⁢Uu,k*⁢Uv,k)u,v∈Ik.

{proof}

[Proof of Lemma 4.4] Let T∈H⁢S⁢(H). The equalities π⁢(g)⁢T=T⁢π⁢(g) for every g∈G mean that for every k,l∈J, u∈Ik and v∈Il, πu,k⁢(g)⁢Tu,v=Tu,v⁢πv,l⁢(g) for every g∈G, i. e. πk⁢(g)⁢Uu,k⁢Tu,v⁢Uv,l*=Uu,k⁢Tu,v⁢Uv,l*⁢πl⁢(g) for every g∈G. Thus the operator Su,v=Uu,k⁢Tu,v⁢Uv,l*:\xymatrix⁢Kl⁢\ar⁢[r]⁢&⁢Kk intertwines the two representations πk and πl. If Su,v is non-zero, it follows from Schur’s Lemma that Su,v is an isomorphism. The representations πk and πl are thus isomorphically (and hence unitarily) equivalent. Since πk and πl are not equivalent for k≠l, it follows that Su,v=0, and hence Tu,v=0 for every u∈Ik and v∈Il as soon as k≠l.

If now k=l, the equalities πk⁢(g)⁢Su,v=Su,v⁢πk⁢(g) for every g∈G and Schur’s Lemma again imply that Su,v=λu,v⁢ik for some scalar λu,v, where ik is the identity operator from Kk into itself. So Tu,v=λu,v⁢Uu,k*⁢Uv,k. Thus any operator T∈𝗘π satisfies the two conditions of the lemma. The converse is obvious. The proof of Proposition 4.1 is now straightforward. {proof}[Proof of Proposition 4.1] Consider, for every j∈J and u,v∈Ij, the one-dimensional subspace 𝗘u,v of H⁢S⁢(H) spanned by the operator Vu,v=τu,j⁢Uu,j*⁢Uv,j⁢Pv,j. These subspaces are pairwise orthogonal in HS(H), and by Lemma 4.4 we have

𝗘π=⊕j∈J(⊕u,v∈Ij𝗘u,v).

Hence, for every A∈H⁢S⁢(H), 𝗣π⁢A is the sum of the projections of A on all the subspaces 𝗘u,v, i.e.

𝗣π⁢A=∑j∈J∑u,v∈Ij⟨A,Vu,v||Vu,v||⟩⁢Vu,v||Vu,v||=∑j∈J1dj⁢∑u,v∈Ij𝑡𝑟⁢(Uv,j*⁢Uu,j⁢Au,v)⁢Vu,v,

which gives the formula we were looking for. We also have

||𝗣π⁢A||2=∑j∈J∑u,v∈Ij|⟨A,Vu,v||Vu,v||⟩|2=∑j∈J1dj⁢∑u,v∈Ij|𝑡𝑟⁢(Uv,j*⁢Uu,j⁢Au,v)|2.
Corollary 4.5

Let π be a compact representation of G on H, written π=⊕j∈J(⊕i∈Ijπ)i,j as in Proposition 4.1. Let x=⊕j∈J(⊕\iijx)i,j and y=⊕j∈J(⊕\iijy)i,j be two vectors of H, and let A∈𝐻𝑆(H) be the rank-one operator ⟨∙,y⟩⁢x. Then

𝙋π⁢A=∑j∈J1dj⁢∑u,v∈Ij⟨Uu,j⁢xu,j,Uv,j⁢yv,j⟩⁢τu,j⁢Uu,j*⁢Uv,j⁢Pv,j.
{proof}

For every j∈J and u,v∈Ij, Au,v=⟨∙,yv,j⟩⁢xu,j, so that

tr⁢(Uv,j*⁢Uu,j⁢Au,v)=⟨Uu,j⁢xu,j,Uv,j⁢yv,j⟩.

The result then follows from Proposition 4.1.

4.3 An abstract version of the Wiener Theorem.

As recalled in Section 3, 𝗘π is the space of G-invariant vectors for the representation π⊗π¯ on H⁢S⁢(H), where for every x,y∈H, x⊗y¯ is identified with the rank-one operator ⟨∙,y⟩⁢x. For every pair (x,y) of vectors of H, denote by 𝒃x,y the element of K⊗K, with K=⊕\jnjKj, defined by

𝒃x,y=∑j∈J1dj(∑i∈Ijx⊗i,jy¯)i,j.

It should be pointed out that for a fixed index j∈J the vectors xi,j and yi,j are understood in the formula above as belonging to the same space Kj (and not to the various orthogonal spaces Hi,j). So 𝒃x,y is a vector of K⊗K, not of H⊗H. Thus

||𝒃x,y||2=∑j∈J1dj⁢∑u,v∈Ij⟨xu,j,xv,j⟩⁢⟨yu,j,yv,j⟩¯.

Combining Corollary 4.5 with the formula

m⁢(|⟨π⁢(∙)⁢x,y⟩|2)=⟨Pπ⊗π¯⁢x⊗x¯,y⊗y¯⟩=⟨𝗣π⁢⟨∙,x⟩⁢x,⟨∙,y⟩⁢y⟩

yields

Corollary 4.6

Let π be a compact representation of G on H, written in the form π=⊕j∈J(⊕i∈Ijπ)i,j as in Proposition 4.1. For every vectors x=⊕j∈J(⊕\iijx)i,j and y=⊕j∈J(⊕\iijy)i,j of H,

m⁢(|⟨π⁢(∙)⁢x,y⟩|2) =∑j∈J1dj⁢∑u,v∈Ij⟨Uu,j⁢xu,j,Uv,j⁢xv,j⟩.⟨Uu,j⁢yu,j,Uv,j⁢yv,j⟩¯ (6)
=||𝒃U⁢x,U⁢y||2.

We thus obtain the following abstract version of the Wiener Theorem for unitary representations of a group G:

Theorem 4.7

Let π be a unitary representation of G on a Hilbert space H. We decompose H as H=Hw⁢⊕Hc and π as π=πw⁢⊕πc, where πw is the weakly mixing part of π and πc its compact part. Writing πc=⊕j∈J(⊕i∈Ijπ)i,j as in Corollary 4.6 above, we have for every vectors x,y of H, written respectively x=xw⁢⊕xc and y=yw⁢⊕yc with respect to the decomposition H=Hw⁢⊕Hc,

m⁢(|⟨π⁢(∙)⁢x,y⟩|2)=||𝒃U⁢xc,U⁢yc||2. (7)
{proof}

This follows directly from the facts that

m⁢(|⟨π⁢(∙)⁢x,y⟩|2)=m⁢(|⟨πw⁢(∙)⁢xw,yw⟩|2)+m⁢(|⟨πc⁢(∙)⁢xc,yc⟩|2)

and that m⁢(|⟨πw⁢(∙)⁢xw,yw⟩|2)=0, and from Corollary 4.6.

Theorem 4.7 will be a crucial tool for the proof of our main result, to be given in Section 5. We will also need an inequality on the quantities m⁢(|⟨π⁢(∙)⁢x,y⟩|2) for a compact representation π, which is a direct consequence of Corollary 4.6. Using the same notation as in the statement of Corollary 4.6, we denote by x=⊕j∈Jx~j and y=⊕j∈Jy~j the respective decompositions of the vectors x and y of H with respect to the decomposition H=⊕j∈JH~j of H. Then we have

Corollary 4.8

Let π be a compact representation of G on H. Under the assumptions of Theorem 4.7, we have for every vectors x and y of H

m⁢(|⟨π⁢(∙)⁢x,y⟩|2)≤∑j∈J1dj⁢||x~j||2.||y~j||2≤∑j∈J||x~j||2.||y~j||2.
{proof}

Applying the Cauchy-Schwarz inequality twice to (6) yields that

m⁢(|⟨π⁢(∙)⁢x,y⟩|2) ≤∑j∈J1dj⁢∑u,v∈Ij||xu,j||.||xv,j||.||yu,j||.||yv,j||
=∑j∈J1dj(∑u∈Ij||xu,j||.||yu,j||)2
≤∑j∈J1dj⁢(∑u∈Ij||xu,j||2).(∑u∈Ij||yu,j||2)
=∑j∈J1dj⁢||x~j||2.||y~j||2≤∑j∈J||x~j||2.||y~j||2

since dj≥1 for every j∈J.

4.4 Why is (7) an abstract version of the Wiener Theorem?

Recall that the classic Wiener Theorem states that for any probability measure σ on the unit circle 𝕋,

\xymatrix⁢@⁢C=60⁢p⁢t⁢12⁢N+1⁢∑n=-NN|σ^⁢(n)|2⁢\ar⁢[r]⁢\ar⁢@⁢@⁢<.6⁢e⁢x>⁢[r]-⁢\xymatrix⁢@C=13ptN\ar[r]&+⁢∞⁢&⁢∑λ∈𝕋σ⁢({λ})2. (8)

The operator Mσ of multiplication by ei⁢θ on L2⁢(𝕋,σ) is unitary, and thus induces a unitary representation πσ of ℤ on L2⁢(𝕋,σ). Its compact part πσd is induced by the multiplication operator by ei⁢θ on L2⁢(𝕋,σd), where σd is the discrete part of σ: σd=∑λ∈Dσ({λ})δλ, with D={λ∈𝕋;σ({λ})>0}. We have L2⁢(𝕋,σd)=⊕λ∈DL2⁢(𝕋,σ⁢({λ})⁢δλ), and πσd=⊕λ∈Dπδλ, where each πδλ is the one-dimensional irreducible representation on L2⁢(𝕋,σ⁢({λ})⁢δλ) given by multiplication by λ. The representations πδλ are pairwise non-equivalent. Hence the operator U (defined in Section 4.1) involved in the decomposition of πσd as a direct sum of irreducible representations is equal to the identity operator on L2⁢(𝕋,σ) and we have for every functions f and g of L2⁢(𝕋,σ)

||𝒃f,g||2=∑λ∈D|f⁢(λ)|2.|g⁢(λ)|2.σ⁢({λ})2.

Applying Theorem 4.7 to the functions f=g=1 and remembering that

m⁢(F)=limN→+∞⁡12⁢N+1⁢∑n=-NNF⁢(n)

for every F∈WAP(ℤ) yields (8).

As seen above in the case where G=ℤ, Theorem 4.7 admits a much simpler formulation in the case where G is an abelian group: all irreducible representations are one-dimensional and either equal or non-equivalent, so that U is the identity operator on H. If π is a compact representation of G, the formula (6) thus becomes in this case

m⁢(|⟨π⁢(∙)⁢x,y⟩|2)=∑j∈J∑u,v∈Ijxu,j⁢x¯v,j⁢y¯u,j⁢yv,j

since xi,j and yi,j, i∈Ij, j∈J, are simply scalars. Using the notation of Corollary 4.8, we have

m⁢(|⟨π⁢(∙)⁢x,y⟩|2)=∑j∈J|∑u∈Ijxu,j⁢y¯u,j|2=∑j∈J|⟨x~j,y~j⟩|2. (9)

For every character χ∈Γ (where Γ denotes the dual group of G), we denote by Eχ the subspace of H

Eχ={x∈H;π(g)x=χ(g)xfor everyg∈G}

and by Pχ the orthogonal projection of H on Eχ. Each representation πj, j∈J, being in fact a character χj on the group G, we can identify the space H~j with Eχj. Equation (9) then yields the following corollary:

Corollary 4.9

Let G be an abelian group, and let π be a representation of G on a Hilbert space H. Then we have for every x,y∈H

m⁢(|⟨π⁢(∙)⁢x,y⟩|2)=∑j∈J|⟨PEχj⁢x,PEχj⁢y⟩|2=∑χ∈Γ|⟨PEχ⁢x,PEχ⁢y⟩|2.

In particular, if x=y,

m⁢(|⟨π⁢(∙)⁢x,x⟩|2)=∑χ∈Γ||PEχ⁢x||4.

Specializing Corollary 4.9 to the case where G=ℤ yields the well-known result (see for instance [3] or [22]) that for any unitary operator U on H, and any vectors x,y∈H,

\xymatrix⁢@⁢C=60⁢p⁢t⁢12⁢N+1⁢∑n=-NN|⟨Un⁢x,y⟩|2⁢\ar⁢[r]⁢\ar⁢@⁢@⁢<.6⁢e⁢x>⁢[r]-⁢\xymatrix⁢@C=13ptN\ar[r]&+⁢∞⁢&⁢∑λ∈𝕋|⟨Pker⁡(U-λ⁢IdH)⁢x,Pker⁡(U-λ⁢IdH)⁢y⟩|2.

In particular, we have

\xymatrix⁢@⁢C=60⁢p⁢t⁢12⁢N+1⁢∑n=-NN|⟨Un⁢x,x⟩|2⁢\ar⁢[r]⁢\ar⁢@⁢@⁢<.6⁢e⁢x>⁢[r]-⁢\xymatrix⁢@C=13ptN\ar[r]&+⁢∞⁢&⁢∑λ∈𝕋||Pker⁡(U-λ⁢IdH)⁢x||4.

We refer the reader to [1, 2, 3, 10, 22] and the references therein for related aspects and generalizations of the Wiener Theorem.

We now have all the necessary tools for the proof of Theorem 2.7, which we present in the next section.

5 Proof of Theorem 2.7

5.1 Notation

Let (Wn)n≥1 be an increasing sequence of subsets of G satisfying the assumptions of Theorem 2.7, and let Q be a subset of G. For each n≥1, we denote by Qn the set Qn=Wn∪Q. Remark that G is the increasing union of the sets Qn, n≥1.

In order to prove Theorem 2.7, we argue by contradiction, and suppose that property (* ‣ 2.7) of Theorem 2.7 holds true, while Qn is a non-Kazhdan set in G for every n≥1. We will then construct for every ε>0 a representation π of G which admits a (Q,ε)-invariant vector, but is weakly mixing (which, by Proposition 3.1, is equivalent to the fact that π has no finite dimensional subrepresentation), and this will contradict (* ‣ 2.7). We denote by ε0 a positive constant such that assumption (* ‣ 2.7) holds true: any representation of G admitting a (Q,ε0)-invariant vector has a finite dimensional subrepresentation.

5.2 Construction of a sequence (πn)n≥1 of finite dimensional representations of G

The first step of the proof is to show that assumption (* ‣ 2.7) combined with the hypothesis that Qn is a non-Kazhdan set for every n≥1 implies the existence of sequences of finite dimensional representations of G with certain properties.

Lemma 5.1

For every sequence (εn)n≥1 of positive real numbers decreasing to zero with ε1∈(0,ε0], there exist a sequence (Hn)n≥1 of finite dimensional Hilbert spaces and a sequence (πn)n≥1 of unitary representations of G such that for every n≥1, πn is a representation of G on Hn with the following two properties:

  1. –

    πn has no non-zero G-invariant vector;

  2. –

    πn has (Qn,εn)-invariant unit vector an∈Hn: ||an||=1 and

    supg∈Qn⁡||πn⁢(g)⁢an-an||<εn.
{proof}

[Proof of Lemma 5.1] Let n≥1. Since Qn is a not a Kazhdan set in G, there exists a representation ρn of G on a Hilbert space Kn which has no non-zero G-invariant vector, but is such that there exists a unit vector xn∈Kn with

supg∈Qn⁡||ρn⁢(g)⁢xn-xn||<εn.

Since εn≤ε0, assumption (* ‣ 2.7) implies that ρn has a finite dimensional subrepresentation. By Proposition 3.1, ρn is not weakly mixing. This means that if we decompose Kn as Kn=Kn,w⁢⊕Kn,c and ρn as ρn=ρn,w⁢⊕ρn,c, where ρn,w and ρn,c are respectively the weakly mixing and compact parts of G, ρn,c is a non-zero representation. Since ρn has no non-zero G-invariant vector, neither have ρn,w nor ρn,c.

Decomposing xn as xn=xn,w⁢⊕xn,c, we have 1=||xn,w||2+||xn,c||2. We claim that lim¯n→+∞⁢||xn,c||>0. Indeed, suppose that it is not the case. Then lim¯n→+∞⁢||xn,w||=1. Since ||ρn(g)xn-xn||2=||ρ(g)n,wxn,w-xn,w||2+||ρn,c(g)xn,c-xn,c||2 for every g∈G, we have

supg∈Qn⁡||ρn,w⁢(g)⁢xn,w-xn,w||<εn,
so that
supg∈Qn⁡||ρn,w⁢(g)⁢xn,w||xn,w||-xn,w||xn,w||||<εn||xn,w||

as soon as xn,w is non-zero. Since lim¯n→+∞⁢||xn,w||=1 and since (εn)n≥1 is decreasing, this implies that for any δ>0 there exists an integer n such that ρn,w has a (Qn,δ)-invariant vector of norm 1. Applying this to δ=ε0, there exists n0≥1 such that ρn0,w has a (Qn0,ε0)-invariant vector, hence a (Q,ε0)-invariant vector. But ρn0,w is weakly mixing, so has no finite dimensional subrepresentation. This contradicts assumption (* ‣ 2.7). So we deduce that lim¯n→+∞⁢||xn,c||=γ>0. The same observation as above, applied to the representation ρn,c, shows that

supg∈Qn⁡||ρn,c⁢(g)⁢xn,c||xn,c||-xn,c||xn,c|||| <εn||xn,c||
for every n such that xn,c is non-zero, and thus that
supg∈Qn⁡||ρn,c⁢(g)⁢xn,c||xn,c||-xn,c||xn,c|||| <2⁢εnγ

for infinitely many integers n. For these integers, ρn,c is a compact representation for which yn=xn,c/||xn,c|| is a (Qn,2⁢εn/γ)-invariant vector of norm 1. It has no non-zero G-invariant vector. Since ρn,c is compact, it can be decomposed as a direct sum of finite dimensional representations: ρn,c=⊕l∈Lnρn,c(l), where Kn,c=⊕l∈LnKn,c(l), each space Kn,c(l) is finite dimensional, ρn,c(l) is a representation of G on Kn,c(l), and Ln is a certain set of indices. If Ln is finite, ρn,c is already a finite dimensional representation of G with a (Qn,2⁢εn/γ)-invariant vector and no non-zero G-invariant vector. So suppose that Ln is infinite: writing yn as yn=⊕l∈Lnyn(l) with respect to the decomposition Kn,c=⊕l∈LnKn,c(l), we have for every finite subset F of Ln and every g∈Qn

||⊕l∈Ln∩Fρ(g)n,c(l)(⊕l∈Ln∩Fyn(l))-⊕l∈Ln∩Fyn(l)||2 <(2⁢εnγ)2+∑l∈Ln∖F||ρn,c(l)⁢(g)⁢yn(l)-yn(l)||2
<(2⁢εnγ)2+∑l∈Ln∖F4⁢||yn(l)||2.

Since ||yn||2=∑l∈Ln||yn(l)||2=1, there exists a finite subset F of L such that the remainder term ∑l∈Ln∖F4⁢||yn(l)||2 is less than (εn/γ)2. It follows that

supg∈Qn||⊕l∈Ln∩Fρn,c(l)(g)(⊕l∈Ln∩Fyn(l))-⊕l∈Ln∩Fyn(l)||2<5(εnγ)2⋅

Recalling that

||⊕l∈Ln∩Fyn(l)||2=∑l∈Ln∩F||yn(l)||2>1-(εn2⁢γ)2,

we thus obtain that (for n large enough) ⊕l∈Ln∩Fρn,c(l) is a finite dimensional representation of G having no non-zero G-invariant vector but admitting a (Qn,4⁢εn/γ)-invariant vector. Summing things up, we obtain that there exists for infinitely many integers n≥1 a finite dimensional representation σn of G with a (Qn,4⁢εn/γ)-invariant vector but no non-zero G-invariant vector. Since (εn)n≥1 decreases to zero, Lemma 5.1 follows immediately.

5.3 Kazhdan property for ampliations of finite dimensional irreducible representations

In order to complete the proof of Theorem 2.7, we need to consider separately two cases, depending on whether or not infinitely many of the non-Kazhdan sets Qn satisfy a weak form of the Kazhdan property, which we call the Kazhdan property for ampliations of finite dimensional irreducible representations. Let us first introduce the following definition.

Definition 5.2

Let C be a class of representations of G on a Hilbert space. We say that a subset Q of G is a Kazhdan set for the class 𝒞 if there exists a positive constant ε′ such that the following holds true: if π is a representation of G belonging to C which admits a (Q,ε′)-invariant vector, then π has a non-zero G-invariant vector.

Kazhdan’s Property (T) for particular classes of representations is a much studied topic. For instance Property (τ) for discrete groups (see, among other references [32] or [41]) is Property (T) for the class of representations which factor through a finite index subgroup.

We will consider here the class 𝒞0 consisting of all ampliations of finite dimensional irreducible representations of G. These are the representations of G of the form

πI=⊕i∈Iπi,

where I is a finite or infinite set of indices, and πi=π for every i∈I, with π an irreducible representation of G on a finite dimensional space H. The representation πI is thus a representation of G on HI=⊕i∈IHi, with Hi=H for every i∈I. When no confusion arises, we simply write πI=⊕i∈Iπ and HI=⊕i∈IH.

Fact 5.3

Let Q be a subset of a topological group G. The following assertions are equivalent:

  • (α)

    Q has the Kazhdan property for ampliations of finite dimensional irreducible representations, with associated constant ε′;

  • (β)

    let π be a finite dimensional irreducible representation of G on H, and let (xi)i∈I be a finite or infinite family of vectors of H. If

    supg∈Q⁡(∑i∈I||π⁢(g)⁢xi-xi||2)1/2<ε′⁢(∑i∈I||xi||2)1/2,

    then π is the unit representation 𝟙G;

  • (γ)

    let π be a finite dimensional irreducible representation of G on H, and let (xi)i∈I be a finite family of vectors of H. If

    supg∈Q⁡(∑i∈I||π⁢(g)⁢xi-xi||2)1/2<ε′⁢(∑i∈I||xi||2)1/2,

    then π=𝟙G.

{proof}

Let π be a finite dimensional irreducible representation of G on a Hilbert space H, and let I be a finite or infinite set of indices. Then a vector x=⊕i∈Ixi of ⊕i∈IH is a (Q,ε′)-invariant vector for πI if and only if

supg∈Q⁡||πI⁢(g)⁢x-x||=supg∈Q⁡(∑i∈I||π⁢(g)⁢xi-xi||2)1/2<ε′⁢(∑i∈I||xi||2)1/2.

So property (β) is equivalent to the fact that if π is a finite dimensional irreducible representation having an ampliation with a (Q,ε′)-invariant vector, π=𝟙G. Since π is assumed to be irreducible, π has a non-zero G-invariant vector if and only if π=𝟙G. Thus properties (α) and (β) are equivalent. That (β) implies (γ) is obvious. Suppose now that (γ) holds true. Let π be a finite dimensional irreducible representation of G on H, and let (xi)i∈I be an infinite family of vectors of H such that

supg∈Q⁡(∑i∈I||π⁢(g)⁢xi-xi||2)1/2<ε′⁢(∑i∈I||xi||2)1/2.

There exists a δ>0 such that

supg∈Q⁡∑i∈I||π⁢(g)⁢xi-xi||2<(ε′⁣ 2-δ)⁢∑i∈I||xi||2.

For any finite subset F of I, we have

supg∈Q⁡∑i∈F||π⁢(g)⁢xi-xi||2 <ε′⁣ 2⁢∑i∈F||xi||2+ε′⁣ 2⁢∑i∈I∖F||xi||2.

It is not difficult to see that if the finite set F is sufficiently large,

(ε′⁣ 2-δ)⁢∑i∈I∖F||xi||2<δ⁢∑i∈F||xi||2.

We then have

supg∈Q⁡(∑i∈F||π⁢(g)⁢xi-xi||2)1/2<ε′⁢(∑i∈F||xi||2)1/2.

By property (γ), π=𝟙G. This finishes the proof of Fact 5.3.

Let us now go back to the different cases in the proof of Theorem 2.7.

5.4 Case 1

Suppose that there exists an integer n0 such that Qn0 is a Kazhdan set for ampliations of finite dimensional irreducible representations, with associated constant ε0′. Then, since (Qn)n≥1 is an increasing sequence of sets, Qn is for every n≥n0 a Kazhdan set for ampliations of finite dimensional irreducible representations with a common associated constant ε0′.

Let now ε>0 be an arbitrary positive number. We fix a sequence (εn)n≥1 of positive numbers decreasing to zero so fast that the following properties hold:

  1. (i)

    0<εn<ε0 for every n≥1, and ∑n≥1εn<ε2/2;

  2. (ii)

    for every n≥n0, εn<2-n⁢ε0′.

This sequence (εn)n≥1 being fixed, we consider the representation 𝝅=⊗n≥1πn of G on the infinite tensor product space 𝑯=⊗n≥1𝒂Hn, where the spaces Hn, the representations πn and the vectors an are associated to εn for each n≥1 by Lemma 5.1. Our aim is to prove the following:

Proposition 5.4

Under the assumptions above, 𝛑 is well-defined and enjoys the following properties:

  1. (a)

    𝝅 is a strongly continuous representation of G on 𝑯=⊗n≥1𝒂Hn;

  2. (b)

    𝝅 has a (Q,ε)-invariant vector;

  3. (c)

    𝝅 is weakly mixing.

Proposition 5.4 proves the existence, for every ε>0, of a representation of G with a (Q,ε)-invariant vector but no finite dimensional subrepresentation. This clearly violates assumption (* ‣ 2.7) of Theorem 2.7. It thus suffices to prove Proposition 5.4 to conclude the proof of Theorem 2.7 under the additional assumption of Case 1. {proof}[Proof of Proposition 5.4] We will prove successively properties (a) to (c), the hardest one being property (c).

Proof of property (a). In order to prove that 𝝅 is well-defined and strongly continuous, it suffices to check that the assumptions of Proposition A.2 in the appendix hold true. For every g∈G and n≥1, we have |1-⟨πn⁢(g)⁢an,an⟩|≤||πn⁢(g)⁢an-an|| so that

supg∈Qn⁡|1-⟨πn⁢(g)⁢an,an⟩|<εn.

By assumption (i), the series ∑n≥1εn is convergent. Since every element g∈G belongs to all the sets Qn except finitely many, the series ∑n≥1|1-⟨πn⁢(g)⁢an,an⟩| is convergent for every g∈G. Moreover, it is uniformly convergent on Q1, and hence on W1. The function

\xymatrix⁢g⁢\ar⁢@⁢|->⁢[r]⁢&⁢∑n≥1|1-⟨πn⁢(g)⁢an,an⟩|

is thus continuous on W1, which is a neighborhood of e. It follows then from Proposition A.2 that 𝝅 is strongly continuous on 𝑯. If G is locally compact, Proposition A.1 and the first part of the argument above suffice to show that 𝝅 is strongly continuous, even when W1 is not a neighborhood of e.

Proof of property (b). It is easy to check that the elementary vector 𝒂=⊗n≥1an of ⊗n≥1𝒂Hn satisfies ||𝒂||=1 and supg∈Q⁡||𝝅⁢(g)⁢𝒂-𝒂||<ε. Indeed ||𝒂||=∏n≥1||an||=1, and for every g∈Q we have (using the fact that Q⊆Qn for every n≥1)

||𝝅⁢(g)⁢𝒂-𝒂||2 =2⁢(1-ℜ⁡e⁢⟨𝝅⁢(g)⁢𝒂,𝒂⟩)≤2⁢|1-∏n≥1⟨πn⁢(g)⁢an,an⟩|
≤2⁢∑n≥1|1-⟨πn⁢(g)⁢an,an⟩|<2⁢∑n≥1εn.

Assumption (i) on the sequence (εn)n≥1 implies that supg∈Q⁡||𝝅⁢(g)⁢𝒂-𝒂||2<ε2, and 𝒂 is thus a (Q,ε)-invariant vector for 𝝅.

Proof of property (c). It remains to show that 𝝅 is weakly mixing. By Proposition A.3, it suffices to prove that lim¯n→+∞⁢m⁢(|⟨πn⁢(∙)⁢an,an⟩|2)=0, where m denotes as in the appendix and in Section 3 the invariant mean on WAP(G). Let n≥n0. Using the notation of Section 4.1, we write πn and Hn as

πn=⊕j∈Jn(⊕i∈Ij,nπi,j,n) and Hn=⊕j∈Jn(⊕i∈Ij,nHi,j,n)

respectively. Since Hn is finite dimensional, all the sets Jn and Ij,n, j∈Jn, are finite. For every j∈Jn, Hi,j,n=Kj,n, which is of dimension dj,n. We have, using again the notation of Section 4.1,

πi,j,n=Ui,j,n*⁢πj,n⁢Ui,j,n,j∈Jn,i∈Ij,n.

Recall that πj,n is an irreducible representation of G on Kj,n, that the representations πj,n for distinct j are mutually inequivalent, and that Ui,j,n is for each j∈Jn and i∈Ij,n a unitary operator from Hi,j,n into Kj,n. We also decompose an∈Hn as an=⊕j∈Jn(⊕i∈Ij,nai,j,n). We have

||an||=∑j∈Jn∑i∈Ij,n||ai,j,n||2=1

and

||πn⁢(g)⁢an-an||2 =∑j∈Jn∑i∈Ij,n||π\ijna-i,j,nai,j,n||2
=∑j∈Jn∑i∈Ij,n||πj,n(g)U\ijna-i,j,nU\ijna|i,j,n|2 (10)

for every g∈G. In order to simplify the notation, we set bi,j,n=U\ijnai,j,n for every j∈Jn and every i∈Ij,n. It follows from (10) that we have for every j∈Jn

supg∈Qn⁡(∑i∈Ij,n||πj,n⁢(g)⁢bi,j,n-bi,j,n||2)1/2<εn. (11)

Let us stress here that each vector bi,j,n, j∈Jn, i∈Ij,n, belongs to Kj,n. It is at this point that we use the fact that Qn is a Kazhdan set for ampliations of finite dimensional irreducible representations for every n≥n0, with associated constant ε0′: since πj,n is irreducible, and different from 𝟙G (as πn has no non-zero G-invariant vector), it follows from Fact 5.3 and (11) that

εn>ε0′⁢(∑i∈Ij,n||bi,j,n||2)1/2.

Remembering that (with the notation of Section 4.3) ∑i∈Ij,n||bi,j,n||2=||b~j,n||2=||a~j,n||2, we thus get that

||a~j,n||<εnε0′

for every j∈Jn. Using Corollary 4.8, the fact that ∑j∈Jn||a~j,n||2=||an||2=1, and assumption (ii) on the sequence (εn)n≥1, we obtain that

m⁢(|⟨πn⁢(∙)⁢an,an⟩|2)≤∑j∈Jn||a~j,n||4≤maxj∈Jn⁢||a~j,n||2.∑j∈Jn||a~j,n||2<(εnε0′)2<4-n.

It follows that m⁢(|⟨πn⁢(∙)⁢an,an⟩|2) tends to zero as n tends to infinity. So 𝝅 is weakly mixing by Proposition A.3, and Proposition 5.4 is proved.

5.5 Case 2

Suppose that Qn is never a Kazhdan set for ampliations of finite dimensional irreducible representations. Let ε>0 be an arbitrary positive number. We fix a sequence (εn)n≥1 of positive numbers decreasing to zero so fast that the following properties hold true:

  1. (i)

    ∑n≥1εn<ε2/2;

  2. (ii)

    for every n≥1, 1n+1⁢∑j=n2⁢nεj2<εn2.

Our additional assumption on the sets Qn implies by Fact 5.3 that there exists, for every n≥1, an irreducible representation πn of G on a finite dimensional Hilbert space Hn, without non-zero G-invariant vectors, and a finite family (ai,n)i∈In of vectors of Hn (with In⊆ℕ) such that

(∑i∈In||ai,n||2)1/2=1 and supg∈Qn⁡(∑i∈In||πn⁢(g)⁢ai,n-ai,n||2)1/2<εn. (12)

If we write

H~n=⊕i∈InHn,a~n=⊕i∈Inai,n,and π~n=⊕i∈Inπn,

this means that ||a~n||=1 and supg∈Qn⁡||π~n⁢(g)⁢a~n-a~n||<εn.

Now we again have to consider separately two cases.

5.5.1 Case 2.a

There exists an infinite subset D of ℕ such that whenever k and l are two distinct elements of D, πk and πl are not equivalent. Replacing the sequence (πn)n≥1 by (πn)n∈D, we can suppose without loss of generality that for every distinct integers m and n, with m,n≥1, πm and πn are not equivalent.

Consider for every n≥1 the representation

ρn=π~n⁢⊕⋯⁢⊕π~2⁢n of⁢G⁢on ℋn=H~n⁢⊕⋯⁢⊕H~2⁢n,

and the vector an=1n+1⁢(a~n⁢⊕⋯⁢⊕a~2⁢n) of ℋn, which satisfies ||an||=1. For every g∈Qn we have, since Qn is contained in Qj for every j≥n,

||ρn⁢(g)⁢an-an||2=1n+1⁢∑j=n2⁢n||π~j⁢(g)⁢a~j-a~j||2<1n+1⁢∑j=n2⁢nεj2.

By assumption (ii) on the sequence (εn)n≥1, we obtain that supg∈Qn⁡||ρn⁢(g)⁢an-an||<εn. Let now 𝝆=⊗n≥1ρn be the infinite tensor product of the representations ρn on the space 𝓗=⊗n≥1𝒂ℋn. Using similar tools to those employed in the proof of Proposition 5.4, we are going to show:

Proposition 5.5

Under the assumptions above on the sequence (εn)n≥1, 𝛒 enjoys the following properties:

  1. (a)

    𝝆 is a strongly continuous representation of G on 𝓗=⊗n≥1𝒂ℋn;

  2. (b)

    𝝆 has a (Q,ε)-invariant vector;

  3. (c)

    𝝆 is weakly mixing.

{proof}

[Proof of Proposition 5.5] The proofs of properties (a) and (b) are exactly the same as the ones given in Proposition 5.4, using the fact that supg∈Qn⁡||ρn⁢(g)⁢an-an||<εn for every n≥1. In order to prove that 𝝆 is weakly mixing, we will show as in Proposition 5.4 that m⁢(|⟨ρn⁢(∙)⁢an,an⟩|2) tends to zero as n tends to infinity. Recall that for every n≥1, the representations πn,…,π2⁢n are mutually non-equivalent, so that, with the notation of Section 4.1, Jn={n,…,2⁢n} and Ij,n=In for every j∈Jn. By Corollary 4.8, we have for every n≥1

m(|⟨ρn(∙)an,an⟩|2)≤∑j=n2⁢n||1n+1a~j||4≤maxn≤j≤2⁢n(1n+1||a~j||2)∑j=n2⁢n||a~jn+1||2≤1n+1⋅

So m⁢(|⟨ρn⁢(∙)⁢an,an⟩|2) tends to zero as n tends to infinity. By Proposition A.3, 𝝆 is weakly mixing, and Proposition 5.5 is proved.

The other case we have to consider is when there exists an integer n0≥1 such that for every n≥n0, πn is equivalent to one of the representations π1,…,πn0. Indeed, if there is no such integer, we can construct a strictly increasing sequence (nk)k≥1 of integers such that, for every k≥1, πnk is not equivalent to one of the representations π1,…,πnk-1. The set D={nk;k≥1} then has the property that whenever m and n are two distinct elements of D, πm and πn are not equivalent, and we are back to the setting of Case 1.

5.5.2 Case 2.b

There exists an integer n0≥1 such that for every n≥n0, πn is equivalent to one of the representations π1,…,πn0. There exists hence in this case an index j0∈{1,…,n0} such that πn is equivalent to πj0 for infinitely many integers n. Extracting a subsequence from (πn)n≥1, we can suppose without loss of generality that πn is equivalent to π1 for every n≥1, and so that Hn=H1 for every n≥1. For each n≥1, let Un be a unitary operator on H1 such that πn=Un*⁢π1⁢Un. By (12), there exists for every n≥1 a finite family (ai,n)i∈In of vectors of H1 such that

(∑i∈In||ai,n||2)1/2=1 and supg∈Qn⁡(∑i∈In||π1⁢(g)⁢Un⁢ai,n-Un⁢ai,n||2)1/2<εn.

For each n≥1, set bn=⊕i∈InUn⁢ai,n, seen as a vector of the infinite direct sum H=⊕j≥1H1 by defining its jt⁢h coordinate to be zero when j does not belong to In. Let also π be the infinite ampliation π=⊕j≥1π1 of π1 on H. Then we have, for every n≥1,

||bn||=1 and supg∈Qn⁡||π⁢(g)⁢bn-bn||<εn.

Let now S be a finite subset of G. There exists an integer nS≥1 such that S⊆Qn for every n≥nS, and hence

supg∈S⁡||π⁢(g)⁢bn-bn||<εn for every n≥nS.

It follows that π has almost-invariant vectors for finite sets in the sense of [47, Sec. 1.5]: for every δ>0 and every finite subset S of G, π has an (S,δ)-invariant vector. This implies that π1 itself has almost-invariant vectors for finite sets (see [47, Sec. 1.5] or [36]). Since π1 is a finite dimensional representation, it follows that π1 has almost-invariant vectors for any subset C of G, and in particular for compact subsets of G. Indeed, let C be any subset of G, and suppose that there exists a δ>0 such that π1 has no (C,δ)-invariant vector. This means that for every x belonging to the unit sphere SH1 of H1, there exists an element gx of C such that ||π1⁢(gx)⁢x-x||>δ. The sets Vx={y∈SH1;||π1(gx)y-y||>δ} form an open covering of SH1. Since SH1 is compact, there exists a finite subset {x1,…,xr} of SH1 such that for every x∈SH1, sup1≤i≤r⁡||π1⁢(gxi)⁢x-x||>δ. If we set S={gx1,…,gxr}, this means that π1 has no (S,δ)-invariant vector, which contradicts what we just proved above.

So π1 has almost-invariant vectors in the sense of [7, Def. 1.1.1], and the unit representation 𝟙G is weakly contained in π1 [7, Cor. F.1.5]. As π1 is finite dimensional, it follows from [7, Cor. F.2.9] that 𝟙G is contained in π1, i. e. that π1 has a non-zero G-invariant vector. This contradicts our initial assumption on π1, and shows that the hypothesis of Case 2.b cannot be fulfilled.

So under the assumption of Case 2, there exists for every ε>0 a representation of G with a (Q,ε)-invariant vector but no finite dimensional subrepresentation (this is Proposition 5.5). This contradicts again assumption (* ‣ 2.7) of Theorem 2.7, and concludes the proof in this second case.

6 Some consequences of Theorem 2.7

We begin this section by proving the two characterizations of Kazhdan sets obtained as consequences of Theorem 2.7.

6.1 Proofs of Corollary 2.8 and Theorem 2.9

Let us first prove Corollary 2.8. {proof}[Proof of Corollary 2.8] Let Q0 be a subset of G which has non-empty interior and which generates G. Denote for each n≥1 by Q0±n the set {g1±1⁢…⁢gn±1;g1,…,gn∈Q0}. Then G=⋃n≥1Q0±n. Let g0 be an element of the interior of Q0. Then g0-1⁢Q0 is a neighborhood of e. There exists n0≥1 such that g0-1 belongs to Q0±n0, and thus Q0±(n0+1) is a neighborhood of e. If we set Wn=Q0±(n0+n) for n≥1, the sequence of sets (Wn)n≥1 is increasing, W1 is a neighborhood of e, and (Wn)n≥1 satisfies the assumptions of Theorem 2.7. So if Q is a subset of G for which assumption (* ‣ 2.7) of Theorem 2.7 holds true, there exists n≥1 such that Q0±(n+n0)∪Q is a Kazhdan set in G. Let ε>0 be a Kazhdan constant for this set. Then ε/(n+n0) is a Kazhdan constant for Q0∪Q, and Q0∪Q is a Kazhdan set in G. If G is locally compact, the same proof holds true without the assumption that Q0 has non-empty interior.

{proof}

[Proof of Theorem 2.9] Let us first show that (a) implies (b). If (a) holds true, then, according to the definition of a Kazhdan set, there exists ε>0 such that the following property holds true: any unitary representation π of G on a complex Hilbert space H with a (Q,ε)-invariant vector has a non-zero G-invariant vector. Without any loss of generality one can assume that ε<2. Let δ=1-ε/2 and consider a unitary representation π of G on a Hilbert space H for which there is a vector x∈H of norm one such that infg∈Q⁡|⟨π⁢(g)⁢x,x⟩|>δ. Then the representation π⊗π¯ of G on H⊗H¯ verifies

⟨π⊗π¯⁢(g)⁢x⊗x¯,x⊗x¯⟩=|⟨π⁢(g)⁢x,x⟩|2>δ2

for every g∈Q. Therefore we have

2⁢ℜ⁡e⁢⟨π⊗π¯⁢(g)⁢x⊗x¯,x⊗x¯⟩=2⁢|⟨π⁢(g)⁢x,x⟩|2>2-ε

for every g∈Q. Hence ∥π⊗π¯⁢(g)⁢x⊗x¯-x⊗x¯∥<ε for every g∈Q. Using (a) we obtain that the representation π⊗π¯ of G on H⊗H¯ has a non-zero G-invariant vector. It follows from Proposition 3.1 that π has a finite dimensional subrepresentation. Thus (b) is true. Suppose now that (b) holds true for some δ∈(0,1). Let ε=2⁢(1-δ) and consider a unitary representation π of G on a complex Hilbert space H with a (Q,ε)-invariant vector x of norm one. Noticing again that ε2>∥π⁢(g)⁢x-x∥2=2-2⁢ℜ⁡e⁢⟨π⁢(g)⁢x,x⟩ we get that |⟨π⁢(g)⁢x,x⟩|≥ℜ⁡e⁢⟨π⁢(g)⁢x,x⟩>δ for every g∈Q. It follows from (b) that π has a finite dimensional subrepresentation. Thus (b) implies (c). The fact that (c) implies (a) is a consequence of Theorem 2.7.

6.2 Property (T) in σ-compact locally compact groups

As a consequence of Theorem 2.7, we retrieve a characterization of Property (T) due to Bekka and Valette [6], [7, Th. 2.12.9], valid for σ-compact locally compact groups. Recall that a unitary representation π of G on a Hilbert space H has almost-invariant vectors if it has (Q,ε)-invariant vectors for every compact subset Q of H and every ε>0. Then Property (T) can be characterized by the fact that every unitary representation of G with almost-invariant vectors has a non-zero G-invariant vector [7, Prop. 1.2.1]. A result due to Bekka and Valette [6] (see also [7, Th. 2.12.9]) states the following:

Theorem 6.1 ([6])

Let G be a σ-compact locally compact group. Then G has Property (T) if and only if every unitary representation of G with almost-invariant vectors has a non-trivial finite dimensional subrepresentation.

The proof of [6] relies on the equivalence between Property (T) and Property (FH) for such groups [7, Th. 2.12.4]: every affine isometric action of G on a real Hilbert space has a fixed point. As a direct consequence of Theorem 2.7, we will derive a new proof of Theorem 6.1 which does not involve property (FH).

If Q is a subset of a topological group G, and if π is a unitary representation of G on a Hilbert space H, we say that π has Q-almost-invariant vectors if it has (Q,ε)-invariant vectors for every ε>0. The same argument as in [7, Prop. 1.2.1] shows that Q is a Kazhdan set in G if and only if every representation of G with Q-almost-invariant vectors has a non-zero G-invariant vector. As a direct corollary of Theorem 2.9, we obtain the following characterization of Kazhdan sets which generate the group:

Corollary 6.2

Let Q be a subset of a locally compact group G which generates G. Then Q is a Kazhdan set in G if and only if every representation π of G with Q-almost-invariant vectors has a non-trivial finite dimensional subrepresentation.

{proof}

[Proof of Corollary 6.2] The only thing to prove is that if every representation π of G with Q-almost-invariant vectors has a non-trivial finite dimensional representation, Q is a Kazhdan set. For this it suffices to show the existence of an ε>0 such that assumption (* ‣ 2.7) of Theorem 2.7 holds true. The argument is again exactly the same as the one given in [7, Prop. 1.2.1]: suppose that there is no such ε, and let, for every ε>0, πε be a representation of G with a (Q,ε)-invariant vector but no finite dimensional subrepresentation. Then π=⊕ε>0πε has Q-almost-invariant vectors but no finite dimensional subrepresentation (this follows immediately from [7, Prop. A.1.8]), contradicting our initial assumption.

{proof}

[Proof of Theorem 6.1] It is clear that Property (T) implies that every representation of G with almost-invariant vectors has a non-trivial finite dimensional subrepresentation. Conversely, suppose that every representation of G with almost-invariant vectors has a non-trivial finite dimensional subrepresentation. Using the same argument as in the proof of Corollary 6.2, we see that there exists a compact subset Q of G such that assumption (* ‣ 2.7) of Theorem 2.7 holds true. Choosing for (Wn)n≥1 an increasing sequence of compact subsets of G such that ⋃\gnW=nG, Theorem 2.7 implies that there exists an n≥1 such that Wn∪Q is a Kazhdan set in G. Since Wn∪Q is compact, G has Property (T).

6.3 Equidistribution assumptions: proofs of Theorems 2.5, 2.4 and 2.6

Let G be a second countable locally compact group, and let π be a unitary representation of G on a separable Hilbert space H. Such a representation can be decomposed as a direct integral of irreducible unitary representations over a Borel space (see for instance [7, Sec. F.5] or [23]). More precisely, there exists a finite positive measure μ on a standard Borel space Z, a measurable field \xymatrix⁢z⁢\ar⁢@⁢|->⁢[r]⁢&⁢Hz of Hilbert spaces over Z, and a measurable field of irreducible representations \xymatrix⁢z⁢\ar⁢@⁢|->⁢[r]⁢&⁢πz, where each πz is a representation of G on Hz, such that π is unitarily equivalent to the direct integral πμ=∫Z⊕πz⁢𝑑μ⁢(z) on ℋ=∫Z\oplHdz⁢μ⁢(z). The Hilbert space ℋ is the set of equivalence classes of square integrable vector fields \xymatrix⁢z⁢\ar⁢@⁢|->⁢[r]⁢&⁢xz, with xz∈Hz, with respect to the measure μ; πμ is the representation of G on ℋ defined by πμ⁢(g)⁢x=[\xymatrix⁢z⁢\ar⁢@⁢|->⁢[r]⁢&⁢πz⁢(g)⁢xz] for every g∈G and x∈ℋ. If μc and μd denote respectively the continuous and discrete parts of the measure μ, ℋ decomposes as an orthogonal direct sum ℋ=ℋc⁢⊕ℋd, and πμ as a direct sum πμ=πμ,c⁢⊕πμ,d, where

ℋc=∫Z\oplHdz⁢μc⁢(z),πμ,c=∫Z⊕πz⁢𝑑μc⁢(z)
ℋd=∫Z\oplHdz⁢μd⁢(z),πμ,d=∫Z⊕πz⁢𝑑μd⁢(z).

If we denote by Zd the support of μd, which is a countable subset of Z,

ℋd=⊕z∈ZdHz and πμ,d=⊕z∈Zdπz.

It follows that if μ has a non-trivial discrete part, one of the irreducible representations πz is a subrepresentation of πμ. This observation lies at the core of the proof of Theorem 2.4. {proof}[Proof of Theorem 2.4] Our aim is to show that, under the hypothesis of Theorem 2.4, assumption (* ‣ 2.7) of Theorem 2.7 is satisfied. Fix ε∈(0,1) and let π be a representation of G on a Hilbert space H. Since G is second countable, we can suppose that H is separable. Suppose that π admits a (Q,ε)-invariant vector x∈H. By the result recalled above, we can suppose without loss of generality that

π=∫Z⊕πz⁢𝑑μ⁢(z),x=[\xymatrix⁢z⁢\ar⁢@⁢|->⁢[r]⁢&⁢xz],and H=∫Z\oplHdz⁢μ⁢(z),

where μ is a finite positive Borel measure on a standard Borel space Z, \xymatrix⁢z⁢\ar⁢@⁢|->⁢[r]⁢&⁢Hz is a measurable field of Hilbert spaces over Z, \xymatrix⁢z⁢\ar⁢@⁢|->⁢[r]⁢&⁢πz is an associated measurable field of irreducible representations, and \xymatrix⁢z⁢\ar⁢@⁢|->⁢[r]⁢&⁢xz is a square integrable vector field with respect to μ. We have for every k≥1

||π⁢(gk)⁢x-x||2 =2⁢(1-ℜ⁡e⁢⟨π⁢(gk)⁢x,x⟩)=2⁢(1-ℜ⁡e⁢∫Z⟨πz⁢(gk)⁢xz,xz⟩⁢𝑑μ⁢(z))<ε,
so that
ℜ⁡e⁢∫Z1N⁢∑k=1N⟨πz⁢(gk)⁢xz,xz⟩⁢d⁢μ⁢(z)>1-ε2 for every⁢N≥1. (13)

Now, by assumption (3) of Theorem 2.4,

\xymatrix⁢@⁢C=50⁢p⁢t⁢1N⁢∑k=1N⟨π⁢(gk)⁢xz,xz⟩⁢\ar⁢[r]-⁢\xymatrix⁢@C=13ptN\ar[r]&+⁢∞⁢&⁢0 for⁢μ⁢-almost every⁢z∈Z∖Z0,

where Z0 is a subset of Z which is countable. We infer from this that μ⁢(Z0)>0, and thus μ has a non-trivial discrete part. Hence one of the representations πz, z∈Z0, is a subrepresentation of π. Since all irreducible representations of G are supposed to be finite dimensional, π has a finite dimensional subrepresentation. So assumption (* ‣ 2.7) of Theorem 2.7 is satisfied. As Q generates G, it now follows from Theorem 2.9 that Q is a Kazhdan set in G. {proof}[Proof of Theorem 2.5] The proof of Theorem 2.5 is exactly the same as that of Theorem 2.4, using the fact that if G is a locally compact abelian group (not necessarily second countable), any unitary representation of G is equivalent to a direct integral of irreducible representations (see for instance [23, Th. 7.36]). Theorem 2.6 is a direct consequence of Theorem 2.5 and Corollary 2.10. We finish this section with the following remark.

Remark 6.3

When the equidistribution assumption (3) of Theorem 2.4 is satisfied, but Q does not generate G, the same proof shows that Q becomes a Kazhdan set when one adds to it a suitable “small” perturbation. More precisely:

Theorem 6.4

Let G be a second countable locally compact Moore group, and let (Wn)n≥1 be an increasing sequence of subsets of G such that ⋃\gnW=nG. Let (gk)k≥1 be a sequence of elements of G which satisfies the following assumption:

for all irreducible representations π of G on a Hilbert space H, except at most countably many, \xymatrix⁢@⁢C=50⁢p⁢t⁢1N⁢∑k=1N⟨π⁢(gk)⁢x,y⟩⁢\ar⁢[r]-⁢\xymatrix⁢@C=13ptN\ar[r]&+⁢∞⁢&⁢0 for every⁢x,y∈H. (14)

Set Q={gk;k≥1}. There exists n≥1 such that Wn∪Q is a Kazhdan set in G.

7 Examples and applications

We present in this section some more examples of Kazhdan sets in different kinds of groups, some statements being obtained as consequences of Theorems 2.7, 2.9 or 2.10. We do not try to be exhaustive, and our aim here is rather to highlight some interesting phenomena which appear when looking for Kazhdan sets, as well as the connections of these phenomena with some remarkable properties of the group. We begin with the simplest case, that of locally compact abelian (LCA) groups.

7.1 Kazhdan sets in locally compact abelian groups

Let G be a second countable LCA group, the dual group of which we denote by Γ. If σ is a finite Borel measure on Γ, recall that its Fourier-Stieljes transform is defined by

σ^⁢(g)=∫Γγ⁢(g)⁢𝑑σ⁢(γ) for every⁢g∈G.

The spectral theorem for unitary representations of G acting on a (separable) Hilbert space easily yields the following characterization of Kazhdan subsets of G in terms of Fourier coefficients of probability measures on Γ.

Proposition 7.1

Let Q be a subset of a second countable LCA group G. The following assertions are equivalent:

  1. (1)

    Q is a Kazhdan set in G;

  2. (2)

    there exists ε>0 such that any probability measure σ on Γ with supg∈Q⁡|σ^⁢(g)-1|<ε satisfies σ⁢({1})>0, where 1 denotes the trivial character on G.

Proposition 7.1 is extremely useful to obtain various examples of Kazhdan and non-Kazhdan sets in classic LCA groups such as ℤd or ℝd. We give here two such examples.

Example 7.2

The set Q={2k+k;k≥0} is a Kazhdan set in Z, while the set Q′={2k;k≥0} is not a Kazhdan set in Z.

{proof}

The sequence (nk)k≥0 defined by nk=2k+k for every k≥0 satisfies the relation 2⁢nk=nk+1+k-1 for every k≥0. If σ is a probability measure on 𝕋 such that supk≥0⁡|σ^⁢(nk)-1|<1/3, it follows from the fact that

|σ^⁢(k-1)-1|≤2⁢|σ^⁢(nk)-1|+|σ^⁢(nk+1)-1| for all⁢k≥1

that supk≥0⁡|σ^⁢(k)-1|<1. Hence σ⁢({1})>0, and Q={nk;k≥0} is a Kazhdan set in ℤ. The fact that Q′ is not a Kazhdan set in ℤ relies on the observation that 2k divides 2k+1 for every k≥0. Using the same construction as the one of [21, Prop. 3.9], one can construct for every ε>0 a continuous probability measure σ on 𝕋, given as an infinite convolution of two-points Dirac measures, such that

supk≥0⁡|σ^⁢(2k)-1|<ε,

and this proves that Q′ is not a Kazhdan set in ℤ.

Remark 7.3

The set {2k+k;k≥0} being lacunary, it follows from a result proved independently by Pollington [48] and De Mathan [42] that there exists a subset A of [0,1] of Hausdorff measure 1 such that for every θ in A, the set of all fractional parts of (2k+k)⁢θ, k≥0, is not dense in [0,1]. One of these numbers θ is irrational, and ((2k+k)⁢θ)k≥0 is of course not uniformly distributed modulo 1.

As a consequence of Theorem 2.9 and of the spectral theorem for unitary representations of the group, we obtain the following characterization of Kazhdan sets which generate the group in any second countable LCA group.

Theorem 7.4

Let G be a second countable LCA group, and let Q a subset of G which generates G. The following assertions are equivalent:

  1. (1)

    Q is a Kazhdan set in G;

  2. (2)

    there exists δ∈(0,1) such that any probability measure σ on Γ with infg∈Q⁡|σ^⁢(g)|>δ has a discrete part;

  3. (3)

    there exists ε>0 such that any probability measure σ on Γ with supg∈Q⁡|σ^⁢(g)-1|<ε has a discrete part.

It is worth stating explicitly the corresponding characterization of non-Kazhdan subsets of G: Q is not a Kazhdan subset of G if and only if there exists for every δ∈(0,1) a continuous probability measure σ on Γ such that infg∈Q⁡|σ^⁢(g)|>δ, or, equivalently, if and only if there exists for every ε>0 a continuous probability measure σ on Γ such that supg∈Q⁡|σ^⁢(g)-1|<ε. If the group G is discrete, Theorem 2.10 combined with the spectral theorem for unitary representations again implies that a subset Q of G is a Kazhdan set in G if and only if Q generates G and either assertion (2) or (3) of Theorem 7.4 holds true.

Theorem 7.4 becomes particularly meaningful in the case of the group ℤ, as it yields a characterization of Kazhdan subsets of ℤ involving some classic sets in harmonic analysis, introduced by Kaufman in [33]. They are called w-sets by Kaufman [34], and Kaufman sets (Ka sets) by other authors, such as Hartman [28], [29].

Definition 7.5

Let Q be a subset of Z, and let δ∈(0,1).

∙ We say that Q belongs to the class Ka if there exists a finite complex-valued continuous Borel measure μ on T such that infn∈Q⁡|μ^⁢(n)|>0, and to the class δ-Ka if there exists a finite complex-valued continuous Borel measure μ on T with μ⁢(T)=1 such that infn∈Q⁡|μ^⁢(n)|>δ.

∙ We say that Q belongs to the class Ka+ if there exists a continuous probability measure σ on T such that infn∈Q⁡|σ^⁢(n)|>0, and to the class δ-Ka+ if there exists a continuous probability measure σ on T such that infn∈Q⁡|σ^⁢(n)|>δ.

Our final characterization of Kazhdan subsets of ℤ is given by Theorem 7.6 below:

Theorem 7.6

Let Q a subset of Z. The following assertions are equivalent:

  1. (1)

    Q is a Kazhdan set in ℤ;

  2. (2)

    Q generates ℤ, and there exists a δ∈(0,1) such that Q does not belong to δ-Ka+.

In particular, if Q generates Z, Q is not a Kazhdan subset of Z if and only if Q belongs to δ-Ka+ for every δ∈(0,1).

It is interesting to remark [29] that a set Q belongs to Ka if and only if it belongs to δ-Ka for every δ∈(0,1). There is no similar statement for the class Ka+: any sufficiently lacunary subset of ℤ, such as Q={3k+k;k≥1}, is easily seen to belong to Ka+; but the same reasoning as in Example 7.2 above shows that this set Q is a Kazhdan subset of ℤ. Thus there exists by Theorem 7.6 a δ∈(0,1) such that Q does not belong to δ-Ka+.

Theorem 2.6 is another powerful tool for exhibiting Kazhdan sets in ℤd or ℝd. Here are typical examples of Kazhdan sets in ℤ or ℝ obtained in this way.

Example 7.7

If p is a non-constant polynomial with integer coefficients such that p⁢(Z) is included in a⁢Z for no integer a∈Z, then Q={p(k);k≥0} is a Kazhdan set in Z.

{proof}

The sequence (λp⁢(k))k≥0 is uniformly distributed in 𝕋 for every λ=e2⁢i⁢π⁢θ with θ∈ℝ∖ℚ (see for instance [37]). By Theorem 2.4, {p⁢(k);k≥0} is a Kazhdan set in ℤ as soon as it generates ℤ, which is the case by our assumption that p⁢(ℤ) is included in a⁢ℤ for no integer a∈ℤ.

Example 7.8

Let p be a non-constant real polynomial, and let Q={p(k);k≥0}. Then (-δ,δ)∪Q is a Kazhdan subset of R for any δ>0.

{proof}

Write p as p⁢(x)=∑j=0daj⁢xj, d≥1, and let r∈{1,…,d} be such that ar≠0. It is well-known that the sequence (e2⁢i⁢π⁢t⁢p⁢(k))k∈ℤ is uniformly distributed in 𝕋 as soon as t⁢ar is irrational. This condition excludes only countably many values of t. Set now Wn=(-n,n) for every integer n≥1. Applying Theorem 6.4, we obtain that there exists n≥1 such that (-n,n)∪Q is a Kazhdan set in ℝ. Let ε>0 be a Kazhdan constant for this set. Fix δ>0. In order to prove that (-δ,δ)∪Q is a Kazhdan set in ℝ, we use Proposition 7.1: let γ be a positive number which will be fixed later on, and let σ be a probability measure on ℝ such that supt∈(-δ,δ)∪Q⁡|σ^⁢(t)-1|<γ. For any a∈ℕ and any t∈(-δ,δ),

2⁢(1-ℜ⁡e⁢σ^⁢(a⁢t))=∫ℝ|ei⁢a⁢t⁢x-1|2⁢𝑑σ⁢(x)≤a2⁢∫ℝ|ei⁢t⁢x-1|2⁢𝑑σ⁢(x)≤2⁢a2⁢ℜ⁡e⁢(1-σ^⁢(t))

so that supt∈(δ,δ)⁡(1-ℜ⁡e⁢σ^⁢(a⁢t))<a2⁢γ. If we choose a>n/δ, we obtain that

supt∈(-n,n)⁡|1-σ^⁢(t)|2≤2⁢supt∈(-n,n)⁡(1-ℜ⁡e⁢σ^⁢(t))<2⁢a2⁢γ.

So if γ is chosen so small that γ<min⁡(ε,ε2/(2⁢a2)), we obtain that

supt∈(-n,n)∪Q⁡|1-σ^⁢(t)|<ε,

and since ε is a Kazhdan constant for (-n,n)∪Q, σ⁢({0})>0. Hence γ is a Kazhdan constant for (-δ,δ)∪Q.

Remark 7.9

It is necessary to add a small interval to the set Q in order to turn it into a Kazhdan subset of R, even when Q generates a dense subgroup of R. Indeed, consider the polynomial p⁢(x)=x+2. The set Q={k+2;k≥0} is not a Kazhdan set in R: for any ε>0, let b∈N be such that |e2⁢i⁢π⁢b⁢2-1|<ε. The measure σ defined as the Dirac mass at the point 2⁢π⁢b satisfies supk≥0⁡|σ^⁢(k+2)-1|<ε, so that, by Proposition 7.1, Q is not a Kazhdan set in R.

We finish this section by exhibiting a link between Kazhdan subsets of ℤd and Kazhdan subsets of ℝd, d≥1. Let Q be a subset of ℤd. Seen as a subset of ℝd, Q is never a Kazhdan set in ℝd. But as a consequence of Theorem 2.7, we see that Q becomes a Kazhdan set in ℝd if we add a small perturbation to it.

Proposition 7.10
