Fix an integer d≥1, and let (Wn)n≥1 be an increasing sequence of subsets of Rd such that ⋃\gnW=nRd. Let Q be a Kazhdan subset of Zd. There exists an n≥1 such that Wn∪Q is a Kazhdan set in Rd. Also, B⁢(0,δ)∪Q is a Kazhdan subset of Rd for any δ>0, where B⁢(0,δ) denotes the open unit ball of radius δ for the Euclidean norm on Rd.

{proof}

Let ε>0 be a Kazhdan constant for Q, seen as a subset of ℤd. Consider a unitary representation π of ℝd on a separable Hilbert space H which admits a (Q,ε2/2)-invariant vector x∈H. We are going to show that π admits a finite dimensional subrepresentation, which by Theorem 2.9 will imply that Wn∪Q is a Kazhdan subset of ℝd for some n≥1.

Without loss of generality we can suppose that π is a direct integral on a Borel space Z, with respect to a finite measure μ on Z, of a family (πz)z∈ℤ of irreducible representations of ℝd. So π is a representation of ℝd on L2⁢(Z,μ). We write elements f of L2⁢(Z,μ) as f=(fz)z∈Z. We suppose that ||x||=1; our hypothesis implies that

sup𝒕∈Q|1-⟨π(𝒕)x,x⟩|<ε22⋅

Each representation πz acts on vectors 𝒕=(t1,…,td) of ℝd as πz⁢(𝒕)=exp⁡(2⁢i⁢π⁢⟨𝒕,𝜽z⟩) for some vector 𝜽z=(θ1,z,…,θd,z) of ℝd. Hence

sup𝒕∈Q|1-∫Ze2⁢i⁢π⁢⟨𝒕,𝜽z⟩|xz|2dμ(z)|<ε22⋅

Consider now the representation ρ of ℤd on L2⁢(Z,μ) defined by \xymatrix⁢ρ⁢(𝒏)⁢f:z⁢\ar⁢@⁢|->⁢[r]⁢&⁢e2⁢i⁢π⁢⟨𝒏,𝜽z⟩⁢fz for every 𝒏=(n1,…,nd)∈ℤd and every f∈L2⁢(Z,μ). We have

sup𝒏∈Q⁡||ρ⁢(𝒏)⁢x-x||2≤2⁢sup𝒏∈Q⁡|1-⟨ρ⁢(𝒏)⁢x,x⟩|<ε2,

and since ε is a Kazhdan constant for Q as a subset of ℤd, ρ has a non-zero ℤd-invariant vector. There exists hence f∈L2⁢(Z,μ) with ||f||=1 such that ρ⁢(𝒏)⁢f=f for every 𝒏∈ℤd. Fix a representative of f∈L2⁢(Z,μ), and set Z0={z∈Z;fz≠0}. Then μ⁢(Z0)>0. For every z∈Z0 we have e2⁢i⁢π⁢⟨𝒏,𝜽z⟩=1 for every 𝒏∈ℤd, which implies that 𝜽z∈ℤd. For each 𝒏=(n1,…,nd)∈ℤd, let Z𝒏={z∈Z0;θi,z=nifor eachi∈{1,…,n}} and H𝒏={f∈L2(Z,μ);f=0μ-a. e. onZ∖Z𝒏}. We have ⋃𝒏∈ℤdZ𝒏=Z0, so there exists 𝒏0∈ℤd such that μ⁢(Z𝒏0)>0. Each subspace H𝒏 is easily seen to be invariant for π, and the representation π𝒏 induced by π on H𝒏 is given by \xymatrix⁢π𝒏⁢(𝒕)⁢f:z⁢\ar⁢@⁢|->⁢[r]⁢&⁢e2⁢i⁢π⁢⟨𝒕,𝒏⟩⁢fz for every 𝒕∈ℝd and every f∈H𝒏. So π admits a subrepresentation of dimension 1 as soon as H𝒏 is non-zero, i. e. as soon as μ⁢(Z𝒏)>0. Since μ⁢(Z𝒏0)>0, π admit a subrepresentation of dimension 1. This finishes the proof of our claim, and an application of Theorem 2.9 shows that Wn∪Q is a Kazhdan set in ℝd for some n≥1. If we choose Wn=B⁢(0,n) for every n≥1, and proceed as in the proof of Example 7.8, we obtain that B⁢(0,δ)∪Q is a Kazhdan set in ℝd for every δ>0. We now move out of the commutative setting, and present a characterization of Kazhdan sets in the Heisenberg groups Hn.

7.2 Kazhdan sets in the Heisenberg groups Hn

The Heisenberg group of dimension n≥1, denoted by Hn, is formed of triples (t,𝒒,𝒑) of ℝ×ℝn×ℝn=ℝ2⁢n+1. The group operation is given by

(t1,𝒒1,𝒑1)⋅(t2,𝒒2,𝒑2)=(t1+t2+12(𝒑1⋅𝒒2-𝒑2⋅𝒒1,𝒒1+𝒒2,𝒑1+𝒑2),

where 𝒑⋅𝒒 denotes the scalar product of two vectors 𝒑 and 𝒒 of ℝn. Unitary representations of Hn are completely classified (see for instance [52, Ch. 2], or [23, Sec. 6.6]): there are two distinct families of such representations, which we denote respectively by (ℱ1) and (ℱ2):

– the representations belonging to the family (ℱ1) are representations of Hn on L2⁢(ℝn), the space of complex-valued square-summable functions on ℝn. They are parametrized by an element of ℝ, which we write as ±λ with λ>0. Then π±λ⁢(t,𝒒,𝒑), (t,𝒒,𝒑)∈ℝ2⁢n+1, acts on L2⁢(ℝn) as

\xymatrix⁢π±λ⁢(t,𝒒,𝒑)⁢u:𝒙⁢\ar⁢@⁢|->⁢[r]⁢&⁢ei⁢(±λ⁢t±λ⁢𝒒⋅𝒙+λ2⁢𝒒⋅𝒑)⁢u⁢(𝒙+λ⁢𝒑)

where u belongs to L2⁢(ℝn). These representations have the following important property, which will appear again in the next subsection:

Fact 7.11

For every ±λ∈R and every u∈L2⁢(Rn),

\xymatrix⁢⟨π±λ⁢(t,𝒒,𝒑)⁢u,u⟩⁢\ar⁢[r]⁢&⁢0 𝑎𝑠 \xymatrix⁢|𝒑|⁢\ar⁢[r]⁢&+∞.
{proof}

This follows directly from the dominated convergence theorem if u has compact support in ℝn. It then suffices to approximate u∈L2⁢(ℝn) by functions with compact support to get the result.

– The representations belonging to the family (ℱ2) are one-dimensional. They are parametrized by elements (𝒚,𝜼) of ℝ2⁢n: for every (t,𝒒,𝒑)∈Hn,

π𝒚,𝜼⁢(t,𝒑,𝒒)=ei⁢(𝒚⋅𝒒+𝜼⋅𝒑).

Our main result concerning Kazhdan sets in Hn is the following:

Theorem 7.12

Let Q be a subset of the Heisenberg group Hn, n≥1. The following assertions are equivalent:

  1. (1)

    Q is a Kazhdan set in Hn;

  2. (2)

    the set Q0={(𝒒,𝒑)∈ℝ2⁢n;∃t∈ℝ,(t,𝒒,𝒑)∈Q} is a Kazhdan set in ℝ2⁢n.

{proof}

The proof of Theorem 7.12 relies on the same kind of ideas as those employed in the proof of Proposition 7.10. We start with the easy implication, which is that (1) implies (2). Suppose that Q is a Kazhdan set in Hn, and let ε>0 be a Kazhdan constant for Q. In order to show that Q0 is a Kazhdan set in ℝ2⁢n, we apply Proposition 7.1: let σ be a probability measure on ℝ2⁢n such that

sup(𝒒,𝒑)∈Q0⁡|σ^⁢(𝒒,𝒑)-1|=sup(𝒒,𝒑)∈Q0⁡|∫ℝ2⁢nei⁢(𝒚⋅𝒒+𝜼⋅𝒑)⁢𝑑σ⁢(𝒚,𝜼)-1|<ε22 (15)

and consider the representation ρ of Hn on L2⁢(ℝ2⁢n,σ) defined by

\xymatrix⁢ρ⁢(t,𝒒,𝒑)⁢f:(𝒚,𝜼)⁢\ar⁢@⁢|->⁢[r]⁢&⁢ei⁢(𝒚⋅𝒒+𝜼⋅𝒑)⁢f⁢(𝒚,𝜼)

for every (t,𝒒,𝒑)∈Hn and every f∈L2⁢(ℝ2⁢n,σ). Then (15) implies that the constant function 𝟙 is a (Q,ε)-invariant vector for ρ. Since (Q,ε) is a Kazhdan pair in Hn, it follows that ρ admits a non-zero Hn-invariant function f∈L2⁢(ℝ2⁢n,σ). Fix a representative of f, and consider the subset A of ℝ2⁢n consisting of pairs (𝒚,𝜼) such that f⁢(𝒚,𝜼)≠0. Then σ⁢(A)>0, and σ-almost every element (𝒚,𝜼) of A satisfies 𝒚⋅𝒒+𝜼⋅𝒑∈2⁢π⁢ℤ for every (𝒒,𝒑)∈ℚ2⁢n. By continuity, 𝒚⋅𝒒+𝜼⋅𝒑 belongs to 2⁢π⁢ℤ for every (𝒒,𝒑)∈ℝ2⁢n, so that (𝒚,𝜼)=(𝟎,𝟎). We have thus proved that σ⁢({𝟎,𝟎})>0, and it follows from Proposition 7.1 that Q0 is a Kazhdan set in ℝ2⁢n.

Let us now prove the converse implication. Suppose that Q0 is a Kazhdan set in ℝ2⁢n, and let 0<ε<3 be a Kazhdan constant for Q0. Let π be a unitary representation of Hn on a separable Hilbert space H, which admits a (Q,ε8)-invariant vector x∈H of norm 1. We write as usual π as a direct integral π=∫Z⊕πz⁢𝑑μ⁢(z), where μ is a finite Borel measure on a standard Borel space Z, and x as (xz)z∈Z, with ∫Z||xz||2⁢𝑑μ⁢(z)=1. We have

sup(t,𝒒,𝒑)∈Q|1-∫Z⟨πz(t,𝒒,𝒑)xz,xz⟩dμ(z)|<ε8⋅ (16)

For every z∈Z, the irreducible representation πz belongs to one of the two families (ℱ1) and (ℱ2). If πz belongs to (ℱ1), we write it as π±λz for some ±λz∈ℝ, and if π belongs to (ℱ2), as π𝒚z,𝜼z for some (𝒚z,𝜼z)∈ℝ2⁢n. Let, for i=1,2, Zi be the subset of Z consisting of the elements z∈Z such that πz belongs to (ℱi). We have xz∈L2⁢(ℝn) for every z∈Z1, and xz∈ℂ for every x∈Z2. We now observe the following:

Lemma 7.13

A Kazhdan subset of R2⁢n contains elements (𝐪,𝐩) such that the Euclidean norm |𝐩| of 𝐩 is arbitrarily large.

{proof}

Let Q0 be a Kazhdan subset of ℝ2⁢n, with Kazhdan constant ε>0, and suppose that there exists a constant M>0 such that |𝒑|≤M for every (𝒒,𝒑)∈Q0. Let δ>0 be such that 2⁢M⁢δ<ε and consider the probability measure on ℝ2⁢n defined by

σ=δ𝟎×𝟙B⁢(𝟎,δ)d⁢𝒑|B⁢(𝟎,δ)|⋅

For every (𝒒,𝒑)∈Q,

|σ^⁢(𝒒,𝒑)-1|=|∫B⁢(𝟎,δ)ei⁢𝒔⋅𝒑⁢d⁢𝒔|B⁢(𝟎,δ)|-1|≤2⁢δ⁢|𝒑|≤2⁢M⁢δ<ε.

But σ⁢({(𝟎,𝟎)})=0, and it follows from Proposition 7.1 that Q0 is not a Kazhdan set in ℝ2⁢n, which is a contradiction.

By Fact 7.11, we have for every x∈Z1

\xymatrix⁢⟨π±λz⁢(t,𝒒,𝒑)⁢xz,xz⟩⁢\ar⁢[r]⁢&⁢0 as⁢\xymatrix⁢@⁢C=10⁢p⁢t⁢|𝒑|⁢\ar⁢[r]⁢&+∞,(t,𝒒,𝒑)∈Hn.

Since |⟨π±λ⁢(t,𝒒,𝒑)⁢xz,xz⟩|≤||xz||2 for every z∈Z1, and ∫Z||xz||2⁢𝑑μ⁢(z)=1, the dominated convergence theorem implies that

\xymatrix⁢∫Z1⟨π±λz⁢(t,𝒒,𝒑)⁢xz,xz⟩⁢𝑑μ⁢(z)⁢\ar⁢[r]⁢&⁢0 as⁢\xymatrix⁢@⁢C=10⁢p⁢t⁢|𝒑|⁢\ar⁢[r]⁢&+∞,(t,𝒒,𝒑)∈Hn.

By Lemma 7.13, there exists an element (t0,𝒒0,𝒑0) of Q with |𝒑0| so large that

|∫Z1⟨π±λz(t0,𝒒0,𝒑0)xz,xz⟩dμ(z)|<ε8⋅

Property (16) implies then that

|1-∫Z2π𝒚z,𝜼z⁢(t0,𝒒0,𝒑0)⁢|xz|2⁢𝑑μ⁢(z)|<ε4

from which it follows that ∫Z2|xz|2⁢𝑑μ⁢(z)>1-ε4, so that ∫Z1||xz||2⁢𝑑μ⁢(z)<ε4. Plugging this into (16) yields that

sup(t,𝒒,𝒑)∈Q|1-∫Z2π𝒚z,𝜼z(t,𝒒,𝒑)|xz|2dμ(z)|<3⁢ε8⋅

Since ∫Z2|xz|2⁢𝑑μ⁢(z)>1-ε/4 and 0<ε<3, we can, by normalizing the family (xz)z∈Z2, suppose without loss of generality that Z=Z2, ∫Z|xz|2⁢𝑑μ⁢(z)=1 and that

sup(t,𝒒,𝒑)∈Q⁡|1-∫Zei⁢(𝒚z⋅𝒒+𝜼z⋅𝒑)⁢|xz|2⁢𝑑μ⁢(z)|<ε. (17)

Consider now the unitary representation ρ of ℝ2⁢n on L2⁢(Z,μ) defined by

\xymatrix⁢ρ⁢(𝒒,𝒑)⁢f:z⁢\ar⁢@⁢|->⁢[r]⁢&⁢ei⁢(𝒚z⋅𝒒+𝜼z⋅𝒑)⁢fz

for every (𝒒,𝒑)∈ℝ2⁢n and every f=(fz)z∈Z∈L2⁢(Z,μ). Then (17) can be rewritten as

sup(t,𝒒,𝒑)∈Q⁡|1-⟨ρ⁢(𝒒,𝒑)⁢x,x⟩|<ε,i.e. sup(𝒒,𝒑)∈Q0⁡|1-⟨ρ⁢(𝒒,𝒑)⁢x,x⟩|<ε.

Since ε is a Kazhdan constant for Q0, the representation ρ admits a non-zero ℝ2⁢n-invariant vector f∈L2⁢(Z,μ). Proceeding as in the proof of (1)⟹(2), we see that for every (𝒒,𝒑)∈ℝ2⁢n, ei⁢(𝒚z⋅𝒒+𝜼z⋅𝒑)⁢f⁢(z)=f⁢(z) μ-almost everywhere on Z, so that there exists a subset Z0 of Z with μ⁢(Z0)>0 such that f⁢(z)≠0 for every z∈Z0, and 𝒚z⋅𝒒+𝜼z⋅𝒑 belongs to 2⁢π⁢ℤ for every z∈Z0 and every (𝒒,𝒑)∈ℚ2⁢n. By continuity, 𝒚z⋅𝒒+𝜼z⋅𝒑 belongs to 2⁢π⁢ℤ for every z∈Z0 and every (𝒒,𝒑)∈ℝ2⁢n, so that (𝒚z,𝜼z)=(𝟎,𝟎) for every z∈Z0. So if we set Z0′={z∈Z;(𝒚z,𝜼z)=(𝟎,𝟎)}, we have μ⁢(Z0′)>0. The function f=𝟙Z0′ is hence a non-zero element of L2⁢(Z,μ), which is clearly an Hn-invariant vector for the representation π. So (Q,ε8) is a Kazhdan pair in Hn, and Theorem 7.12 is proved.

7.3 Kazhdan sets in the 𝒂⁢𝒙+𝒃 group

The underlying space of the a⁢x+b group is (0,+∞)×ℝ, and the group law is given by (a,b)⁢(a′,b′)=(a⁢a′,b+a⁢b′), where (a,b) and (a′,b′) belong to (0,+∞)×ℝ. We denote this group by G. As in the case of the Heisenberg groups, the irreducible unitary representations of G are completely classified (see [23, Sec. 6.7]) and fall within two classes:

– the class (ℱ1) consists of two infinite dimensional representations π+ and π- of G, which act respectively on the Hilbert spaces L2⁢((0,+∞),d⁢s) and L2⁢((-∞,0),d⁢s). They are both defined by the formula

\xymatrix⁢π±⁢(a,b)⁢f:s⁢\ar⁢@⁢|->⁢[r]⁢&⁢a⁢e2⁢i⁢π⁢b⁢s⁢f⁢(a⁢s)

where (a,b)∈G, and f∈L2⁢((0,+∞),d⁢s) in the case of π+, and f∈L2⁢((-∞,0),d⁢s) in the case of π-. It is a direct consequence of the Riemann-Lebesgue lemma that the analogue of Fact 7.11 holds true for the two representations π+ and π- of G:

Fact 7.14

For every f∈L2⁢((0,+∞),d⁢s) and every g∈L2⁢((-∞,0),d⁢s), we have

\xymatrix⁢⟨π+⁢(a,b)⁢f,f⟩⁢\ar⁢[r]⁢&⁢0 𝑎𝑛𝑑 \xymatrix⁢⟨π-⁢(a,b)⁢g,g⟩⁢\ar⁢[r]⁢&⁢0 𝑎𝑠 \xymatrix⁢|b|⁢\ar⁢[r]⁢&+∞.

– the representations of G belonging to the family (ℱ2) are one-dimensional. They are parametrized by ℝ, and πλ is defined for every λ∈ℝ by the formula

πλ⁢(a,b)=ai⁢λ for every⁢(a,b)∈G.

Proceeding as in the proof of Theorem 7.12, we characterize the Kazhdan subsets of the a⁢x+b group in the following way:

Theorem 7.15

Let Q be a subset of the a⁢x+b group G. The following assertions are equivalent:

  1. (1)

    Q is a Kazhdan set in G;

  2. (2)

    the set Q0={t∈ℝ;∃b∈ℝ(et,b)∈Q} is a Kazhdan set in ℝ.

{proof}

The proof is similar to that of Theorem 7.12, and we will not give it in full detail here. Let us first sketch briefly a proof of the implication (1)⟹(2). Suppose that Q is a Kazhdan set in G, and let ε>0 be a Kazhdan constant for Q. Consider a probability measure σ on ℝ such that

supt∈Q0|σ^(t)-1|<ε22⋅ (18)

We associate to σ a representation ρ of G on L2⁢(ℝ,σ) by setting, for every (a,b)∈G and every f∈L2⁢(ℝ,σ), \xymatrix⁢ρ⁢(a,b)⁢f:s⁢\ar⁢@⁢|->⁢[r]⁢&⁢ei⁢s⁢(l⁢n⁢a)⁢f⁢(s). Since

||ρ⁢(a,b)⁢𝟙-𝟙||2≤2⁢|∫ℝ(ei⁢s⁢(ln⁡a)-1)⁢𝑑σ⁢(s)| for every⁢(a,b)∈G,

(18) implies that sup{(a,b);lna∈Q0}⁡||ρ⁢(a,b)⁢𝟙-𝟙||<ε, i. e. sup(a,b)∈Q⁡||ρ⁢(a,b)⁢𝟙-𝟙||<ε. Hence ρ admits a non-zero G-invariant function f∈L2⁢(ℝ,σ), and the same argument as in the proof of Theorem 7.12 shows then that σ⁢({0})>0. The converse implication (2)⟹(1) is proved in exactly the same way as in Theorem 7.12, using the same modifications as those outlined above. The group ℝ2⁢n has to be replaced by the multiplicative group ((0,+∞),×) and the analogue of Lemma 7.13 is that Kazhdan subsets of this group contain elements of arbitrarily large absolute value. If Q0 is a Kazhdan set in ℝ, with Kazhdan constant ε small enough, the same argument as in the proof of Theorem 7.12 (involving the same notation) shows that it suffices to prove the following statement: let μ be a finite Borel measure on a Borel space Z, x=(xz)z∈Z a scalar-valued function of L2⁢(Z,μ) with ∫Z|xz|2⁢𝑑μ⁢(z)=1, and π a representation of G of the form π=∫Z⊕πλz⁢𝑑μ⁢(z) with

sup(a,b)∈Q⁡|1-⟨π⁢(a,b)⁢x,x⟩|=sup{a;lna∈Q0}⁡|1-∫Zei⁢(ln⁡a)⁢λz⁢|xz|2⁢𝑑μ⁢(z)|<ε.

Then the set Z0={z∈Z;λz=0} satisfies μ⁢(Z0)>0. The proof of this statement uses the same argument as the one employed in the proof of Theorem 7.12. It involves the representation ρ of the group ((0,+∞),×) on L2⁢(Z,μ) defined by \xymatrix⁢ρ⁢(a)⁢f:z⁢\ar⁢@⁢|->⁢[r]⁢&⁢ei⁢(ln⁡a)⁢λz⁢fz for every a>0 and every (fz)z∈Z∈L2⁢(Z,μ), and uses the obvious fact that since Q0 is a Kazhdan set in ℝ, {a;ln⁡a∈Q0} is a Kazhdan set in ((0,+∞),×).

Facts 7.11 and 7.14 have played a crucial role in the proofs of Theorems 7.12 and 7.15 respectively, as they allowed us to discard all irreducible representations except the one-dimensional inequalities of the form (16). There are locally compact groups in which all non-trivial irreducible representations have the vanishing property of the matrix coefficients stated in Facts 7.11 or 7.14: these groups are said to have the Howe-Moore property. The study of Kazhdan sets becomes easier in such groups, and it is even possible to characterize Kazhdan sets in groups which do not have Property (T), but have the Howe-Moore property, such as S⁢L2⁢(ℝ). This is the object of the next section.

7.4 Kazhdan sets in groups with the Howe-Moore property

The Howe-Moore property was introduced by Howe and Moore in [30]: a locally compact group G has the Howe-Moore property if whenever π is a unitary representation of G on a Hilbert space H, the following alternative holds true:

  1. –

    either π has a non-zero G-invariant vector;

  2. –

    or whenever x and y are two vectors of H, the matrix coefficient ⟨π⁢(g)⁢x,y⟩ vanishes at infinity in the sense that for any δ>0, the set {g∈G;|⟨π⁢(g)⁢x,y⟩|≥δ} is compact in G.

It was proved in [30] and [55] that connected, non-compact, simple real Lie groups with finite center have the Howe-Moore property. We refer the reader to the references [8], [15], and [14] for more on this topic. If the group G is locally compact and second countable, it follows from the decomposition of unitary representations as direct integrals of irreducible representations that G has the Howe-Moore property if and only if all matrix coefficients of non-trivial irreducible representations vanish at infinity.

The following proposition states that all subsets with non-compact closure are Kazhdan sets in groups with the Howe-Moore property. This testifies of the rigidity of the structure of such groups, and stands in sharp contrast with all the examples we have presented until now.

Proposition 7.16

Let G be a locally compact group with the Howe-Moore property, and let Q be a subset of G. If the closure Q¯ of Q in G is non-compact, Q is a Kazhdan set in G.

{proof}

Let ε∈(0,2), and let π be a representation of G on a Hilbert space H which admits a (Q,ε)-invariant vector x∈H, which we suppose to be of norm 1. Then

supg∈Q⁡(1-ℜ⁡e⁢⟨π⁢(g)⁢x,x⟩)<ε2,so that⁢|⟨π⁢(g)⁢x,x⟩|>1-ε2 for every⁢g∈Q.

Suppose that π has no non-zero G-invariant vector. Since G has the Howe-Moore property, and 1-ε/2>0, the set {g∈G;|⟨π⁢(g)⁢x,x⟩|≥1-ε/2} is compact. It contains Q, hence Q¯, so Q¯ is compact. It follows that if Q¯ is not compact, (Q,ε) is a Kazhdan pair in G for any ε∈(0,2). As a direct consequence of Proposition 7.16, we obtain the following characterization of Kazhdan sets in groups without Property (T), but which have the Howe-Moore property.

Theorem 7.17

Let G be a locally compact group with the Howe-Moore property, but without Property (T). A subset Q of G is a Kazhdan set in G if and only if Q¯ is not compact.

{proof}

We only have to prove that if Q¯ is compact, Q is not a Kazhdan set in G. This follows directly from the observation that since unitary representations are strongly continuous, Q is a Kazhdan set in G as soon as Q¯ is a Kazhdan set in G. Since G does not have Property (T), it admits no compact Kazhdan set, and hence a set with compact closure is not a Kazhdan set. As S⁢L2⁢(ℝ) is a non-compact connected simple real Lie group with finite center, it has the Howe-Moore property. But it does not have Property (T), and so we have:

Example 7.18

The Kazhdan sets in S⁢L2⁢(R) are exactly the subsets of S⁢L2⁢(R) with non-compact closure.

8 Further applications of Kazhdan sets

8.1 Kazhdan sets and local rigidity

It was proved by Rapinchuk [49] that finite dimensional unitary representations of a discrete group G with Property (T) are locally rigid in the following sense: let S be a finite set of generators of G (recall that discrete groups with Property (T) are finitely generated, and that the Kazhdan subsets of such groups are the generating sets), and let d≥1 be an integer. If two d-dimensional unitary representations of G are sufficiently close on S, they are unitarily equivalent. A generalization of this result is given in the next theorem, following an idea from [13].

Theorem 8.1

Let G be a topological group, and let (Q,ε) be a Kazhdan pair for G. Let d≥1 be an integer. For every α>0, there exists β>0 such that the following property holds true: for all unitary representations π1 and π2 of G into a d-dimensional Hilbert space H with

supg∈Q⁡∥π1⁢(g)-π2⁢(g)∥<β,

there exists a unitary operator U on H such that ∥U-I∥<α and π2⁢(g)=U*⁢π1⁢(g)⁢U for every g∈G. If 0<α≤2, we can choose β=α⁢ε/(2⁢d).

{proof}

Without loss of generality we can assume that 0<α≤2. Set β=α⁢ε/(2⁢d) and let π1 and π2 be two representations of G on a d-dimensional Hilbert space H such that supg∈Q⁡∥π1⁢(g)-π2⁢(g)∥<β. Consider the unitary representation ρ of G into the space H⁢S⁢(H) of Hilbert-Schmidt operators on H given by ρ⁢(g)⁢(A)=π1⁢(g)⁢A⁢π2⁢(g)-1 for every g∈G and every A∈H⁢S⁢(H). Denote by |⋅|H⁢S the Hilbert-Schmidt norm on H⁢S⁢(H) and by I the identity operator on H. Then

supg∈Q⁡|ρ⁢(g)⁢(I)-I|H⁢S=supg∈Q⁡|π1⁢(g)-π2⁢(g)|H⁢S≤d⁢supg∈Q⁡∥π1⁢(g)-π2⁢(g)∥<d⁢β.

Therefore

supg∈Q⁡|ρ⁢(g)⁢(d-1/2⁢I)-d-1/2⁢I|H⁢S<β=(α2⁢d)⁢ε.

As (Q,ε) is a Kazhdan pair for G, it follows from [7, Prop. 1.1.9] that there exists a G-invariant vector L′∈H⁢S⁢(H) for ρ which is (α2⁢d)-close to d-1/2⁢I. Then L=d⁢L′ is a G-invariant vector for ρ satisfying

∥L-I∥≤|L-I|H⁢S<α2⋅ (19)

Since α≤2, the operator L is invertible. The equation ρ⁢(g)⁢(L)=L for every g∈G implies that

π2⁢(g)=L-1⁢π1⁢(g)⁢L  for every ⁢g∈G. (20)

Consider now the polar decomposition L=U⁢(L*⁢L)1/2 of L. Using Equation (19) and [13, Lem. 4.5] we obtain that ∥U-I∥<α. The fact that π2⁢(g)=U*⁢π1⁢(g)⁢U for every g∈G is a consequence of Equation (20) and of the fact that (L*⁢L)1/2 is a norm limit of polynomials in L*⁢L.

8.2 Kazhdan sets and asymptotically invariant sequences

Connes and Weiss provide ([16], see also [50]) a characterization of Property (T) for countable groups in terms of ergodicity properties of actions of the group on probability spaces. This result is extended in [7, Th. 6.3.4] to second countable locally compact groups, and a simplified proof is given there. If G is such a group, and (Ω,ℱ,ν) is a probability space, a measure-preserving action (Tg)g∈G of G on (Ω,ℱ,ν) gives rise to a unitary representation πν of G on L2⁢(Ω,ℱ,ν) defined by setting πν⁢(g)⁢f⁢(ω)=f⁢(Tg-1⁢ω) for every f∈L2⁢(Ω,ℱ,ν), g∈G and ω∈Ω. The restriction of πν to the space L02⁢(Ω,ℱ,ν) of functions of L2⁢(Ω,ℱ,ν) of mean zero is denoted by πν0.

The Connes-Weiss characterization of Property (T) is given in terms of asymptotically invariant sequences (An)n≥1 of sets for measure preserving actions of G. Given such an action (Tg)g∈G of G on a probability space (Ω,ℱ,ν), these are the sequences (An)n≥1 of elements of ℱ such that for every compact subset Q of G,

limn→+∞⁡supg∈Q⁡ν⁢(Tg⁢An△An)=0. (21)

Such a sequence (An)n≥1 of sets is non-trivial if infn≥1⁡ν⁢(An)⁢(1-ν⁢(An))>0. A measure-preserving action of G is said to be strongly ergodic if it admits no non-trivial asymptotically invariant sequence.

Theorem 8.2 ([16])

Let G be a second countable locally compact group. The following assertions are equivalent:

  1. (a)

    G has Property (T);

  2. (b)

    every measure-preserving ergodic action of G is strongly ergodic;

  3. (c)

    every measure-preserving weakly mixing action of G is strongly ergodic.

We refer the reader to [7, Sec. 6.3] or [24, Ch. 13] for more on the consequences of Property (T) on the measure-preserving actions of the group. Our aim here is to present a last consequence of Theorem 2.7, which is a Connes-Weiss type characterization of Kazhdan subsets of the group.

Consider a measure-preserving action (Tg)g∈G of G on a probability space (Ω,ℱ,ν), and let Q be a subset of G. A sequence (An)n≥1 of elements of ℱ is said to be Q-asymptotically invariant for this action if (21) holds true for this particular set Q. We will call the action (Tg)g∈G Q-strongly-ergodic if it has no non-trivial Q-asymptotically invariant sequence.

Theorem 8.3

Let G be a second countable locally compact group, and let Q be a subset of G which generates G. The following assertions are equivalent:

  1. (a)

    Q is a Kazhdan set in G;

  2. (b)

    every measure-preserving ergodic action of G is Q-strongly ergodic;

  3. (c)

    every measure-preserving weakly mixing action of G is Q-strongly ergodic.

{proof}

The proof of Theorem 8.3 follows in spirit that of the Connes-Weiss characterization of Property (T) given in [7, Th. 6.3.4], and so we will content ourselves with highlighting the main differences between the two proofs. The proof of (a)⟹(b) is the consequence of the following generalization of [7, Prop. 6.3.2] and the fact that if Q is a Kazhdan set in G, representations of G with Q-almost-invariant vectors have non-zero G-invariant vectors:

Fact 8.4

Let G be a second countable locally compact group, and let Q be a subset of G. If a measure-preserving action of G on a probability space (Ω,F,ν) admits a non-trivial Q-asymptotically invariant sequence, then πν0 has Q-almost-invariant vectors.

The implication (b)⟹(c) is obvious, and we concentrate on the proof of the implication (c)⟹(a). Suppose that assumption (c) holds true, but that Q is not a Kazhdan set in G. By Corollary 6.2, there exists a unitary representation π of G on a Hilbert space H (which, as G is second countable, can be assumed to be separable) which has Q-almost-invariant vectors but no finite dimensional subrepresentation. Let Hℝ denote the space H viewed as a real Hilbert space with the scalar product defined by ⟨x,y⟩ℝ=ℜ⁡e⁢⟨x,y⟩ for every x,y∈H. The representation π acting on Hℝ, denoted by πℝ, is an orthogonal representation of G. It also has Q-invariant vectors but no finite dimensional subrepresentation (if E is a finite dimensional subspace of Hℝ which is invariant by the representation πℝ, E~={λx;x∈E,λ∈ℂ} is a finite dimensional subspace of H which is invariant by π).

We proceed now as in the proof of [7, Th. 6.3.4]. Let K be an infinite dimensional Gaussian subspace of the space Lℝ2⁢(Ω,ℱ,ν) of real-valued square integrable functions on the probability space (Ω,ℱ,ν). Let ϕ:\xymatrix⁢Hℝ⁢\ar⁢[r]⁢&⁢K be an isometric isomorphism, and let ϕ~:\xymatrix⁢S⁢(Hℝ)⁢\ar⁢[r]⁢&⁢Lℝ2⁢(Ω,ℱ,ν) be its extension on the symmetric Fock space of Hℝ. It is an isometric isomorphism, and there exists a measure-preserving action (Tg)g∈G of G on (Ω,ℱ,ν) such that

πν,ℝ⁢(g)⁢ϕ~=ϕ~⁢⊕n≥0Sn⁢(πℝ)⁢(g)⁢for every⁢g∈G,

where πν,ℝ denotes the orthogonal representation of G on Lℝ2⁢(Ω,ℱ,ν) associated to the action (Tg)g∈G. Since πℝ has no finite dimensional subrepresentation, the same argument as in [7, Th. 6.3.4] shows that (Tg)g∈G is a weakly mixing action of G on (Ω,ℱ,ν).

In order to get a contradiction, it remains to show that the action (Tg)g∈G admits a non-trivial Q-asymptotically-invariant sequence. Exactly as in [7, Th. 6.3.4], consider a sequence (ξn)n≥1 of vectors of norm one in Hℝ such that

\xymatrix⁢supg∈Q⁡||πℝ⁢(g)⁢ξn-ξn||⁢\ar⁢[r]⁢&⁢0,i.e. \xymatrix⁢supg∈Q⁡⟨πℝ⁢(g)⁢ξn,ξn⟩⁢\ar⁢[r]⁢&⁢1⁢as⁢\xymatrix⁢n⁢\ar⁢[r]⁢&+∞.

Such a sequence of vectors exists, as πℝ has Q-almost invariant vectors. For every n≥1, let Xn=ϕ⁢(ξn), and An={Xn≥0}. Then ν⁢(An)=1/2 for every n≥1. Define also, for n≥1 and g∈G, αn⁢(g)∈[0,π] by the relation cos⁡αn⁢(g)=⟨πℝ⁢(g)⁢ξn,ξn⟩. Then \xymatrix⁢supg∈Q⁡αn⁢(g)⁢\ar⁢[r]⁢&⁢0 as \xymatrix⁢n⁢\ar⁢[r]⁢&+∞. As ν⁢(Tg⁢An△An)=αn⁢(g)/π for every n≥1 and every g∈G (see [7, Th. 6.3.4] for details), (An)n≥1 is a Q-asymptotically invariant sequence for (Tg)g∈G, which is non-trivial since ν⁢(An)=1/2 for every n≥1. We have thus constructed a weakly mixing action of G which is not Q-strongly ergodic, which contradicts assumption (c).

Remark 8.5

Exactly the same proof shows that if (Qk)k≥1 is an increasing sequence of subsets of G such that, for every k≥1, Qk generates G and Qk is not a Kazhdan set in G, there exists a weakly mixing action of G on a probability space (Ω,F,ν) and a non-trivial sequence (An)n≥1 of elements of F which is, for each k≥1, Qk-asymptotically invariant for this action.

Appendix A Infinite tensor products of Hilbert spaces

We briefly describe in this appendix some constructions of tensor products of infinite families of Hilbert spaces, and of tensor products of infinite families of unitary representations. These last objects play an important role in the proof of Theorem 2.7. We review here the properties and results which we need, following the original works of von Neumann [45] and Guichardet [26].

A.1 The complete and incomplete tensor products of Hilbert spaces

The original construction of the complete and incomplete tensor products of a family (Hα)α∈I of Hilbert spaces is due to von Neumann [45]. It was later on taken up by Guichardet in [26] under a somewhat different point of view, and the incomplete tensor products of von Neumann are rather known today as the Guichardet tensor products of Hilbert spaces. Although these constructions can be carried out starting from an arbitrary family (Hα)α∈I of Hilbert spaces, we will present them here only in the case of a countable family (Hn)n≥1 of (complex) Hilbert spaces.

The complete infinite tensor product ⊗n≥1Hn of the Hilbert spaces Hn is defined in [45, Part II, Ch. 3] in the following way: the elementary infinite tensor products are the elements 𝒙=⊗n≥1xn, where xn belongs to Hn for each n≥1 and the infinite product ∏n≥1||xn|| is convergent in the sense of [45, Def. 2.2.1], which by [45, Lem. 2.4.1] is equivalent to the fact that either xn=0 for some n≥1 or the series ∑n≥1max⁡(||xn||-1,0) is convergent. Sequences (xn)n≥1 with this property are called by von Neumann in [45] C-sequences. A scalar product is then defined on the set of finite linear combinations of elementary tensor products by setting

⟨𝒙,𝒚⟩=∏n≥1⟨xn,yn⟩

for any elementary tensor products 𝒙=⊗n≥1xn and 𝒚=⊗n≥1yn, and extending the definition by linearity to finite linear combinations of such elements. The product defining ⟨𝒙,𝒚⟩ for two elementary vectors 𝒙 and 𝒚 is quasi-convergent in the sense of [45, Def. 2.5.1], i.e. ∏n≥1|⟨xn,yn⟩| is convergent. The value of this quasi-convergent product is ∏n≥1⟨xn,yn⟩ if the product is convergent in the usual sense, and 0 if it is not.

That this is indeed a scalar product which turns the set of finite linear combinations of elementary tensor products into a complex prehilbertian space is proved in [45, Lem. 3.21 and Theorem II]. For any elementary tensor product 𝒙=⊗n≥1xn, ||𝒙||=∏n≥1||xn||. The space ⊗n≥1Hn is the completion of this space for the topology induced by the scalar product. It is always non-separable.

The incomplete tensor products are closed subspaces of the complete tensor product. They are defined by von Neumann using an equivalence relation between sequences (xn)n≥1 of vectors with xn∈Hn for each n≥1 and such that the series ∑n≥1|1-||xn||| is convergent. Such sequences are called C0-sequences. They are C-sequences, and if (xn)n≥1 is a C-sequence such that ∏n≥1||xn||>0 (i. e. (xn)n≥1 is non-zero in ⊗n≥1Hn) then (xn)n≥1 is a C0-sequence. If (xn)n≥1 is a C0-sequence, (xn)n≥1 is bounded, and the series ∑n≥1|1-||xn||2| is convergent.

Two C0-sequences (xn)n≥1 and (yn)n≥1 are equivalent if the series ∑n≥1|1-⟨xn,yn⟩| is convergent. If 𝒜 denotes an equivalence class of C0-sequences for this equivalence relation, the incomplete tensor product ⊗n≥1𝒜Hn associated to 𝒜 is the closed linear span in ⊗n≥1Hn of the vectors 𝒙=⊗n≥1xn, where (xn)n≥1 belongs to 𝒜 [45, Def. 4.1.1]. If 𝒜 and 𝒜′ are two different equivalence classes, the spaces ⊗n≥1𝒜Hn and ⊗n≥1𝒜′Hn are orthogonal, and the linear span of the incomplete tensor products ⊗n≥1𝒜Hn, where 𝒜 runs over all equivalence classes of C0-sequences, is dense in the complete tensor product ⊗n≥1Hn.

If 𝒜 is an equivalence class of C0-sequences, ⊗n≥1𝒜Hn admits another, more transparent description, which runs as follows [45, Lem. 4.1.2], see also [26, Rem. 1.1]: let (an)n≥1 be a sequence with an∈Hn and ||an||=1 for every n≥1, such that the equivalence class of (an)n≥1 is 𝒜 (such a sequence (an)n≥1 does exist: if (xn)n≥1 is any non-zero C0-sequence belonging to 𝒜, xn is non-zero for every n≥1, and we can define a C0-sequence (an)n≥1 by setting an=xn/||xn|| for every n≥1. It is not difficult to check that (an)n≥1 is equivalent to (xn)n≥1, and so belongs to 𝒜). Then ⊗n≥1𝒜Hn coincides with the closed linear span in ⊗n≥1Hn of vectors 𝒙=⊗n≥1xn, where xn=an for all but finitely many integers n≥1. Denoting the vector ⊗n≥1an by 𝒂, we write this closed linear span as ⊗n≥1𝒂Hn (see [26]), and thus ⊗n≥1𝒂Hn=⊗n≥1𝒜Hn, where 𝒜 is the equivalence class of 𝒂. The space ⊗n≥1𝒂Hn is usually called the Guichardet tensor product of the spaces Hn associated to the sequence (an)n≥1. Proposition 1.1 of [26] states the following, which is a direct consequence of the discussion above: if 𝒙=(xn)n≥1 is a C0-sequence which is equivalent to 𝒂, 𝒙 belongs to ⊗n≥1𝒂Hn. Vectors 𝒙 of this form are also said to be decomposable with respect to 𝒂, while vectors 𝒙=(xn)n≥1 with xn=an for all but finitely many indices n are called elementary vectors of ⊗n≥1𝒂Hn.

Suppose that all the spaces Hn, n≥1, are separable. For each n≥1, let (ep,n)1≤p≤pn be a Hilbertian basis of Hn, with 1≤pn≤+∞ and e1,n=an. The family of all elementary vectors 𝒆β=⊗n≥1eβ⁢(n),n of ⊗n≥1𝒂Hn, where β is a map from ℕ into itself such that 1≤β⁢(n)≤pn for every n≥1 and β⁢(n)=1 for all but finitely many integers n≥1, forms a Hilbertian basis of ⊗n≥1𝒂Hn [45, Lem. 4.1.4]. In particular, ⊗n≥1𝒂Hn is a separable complex Hilbert space.

A.2 Tensor products of unitary representations

Let G be a topological group, and let (Hn)n≥1 be a sequence of complex separable Hilbert spaces. Let (an)n≥1 be a sequence of vectors with an∈Hn and ||an||=1 for every n≥1. We are looking for conditions under which one can define a unitary representation 𝝅 of G on ⊗n≥1𝒂Hn which satisfies

𝝅(g)⊗n≥1xn=⊗n≥1πn(g)xn (22)

for every g∈G and every decomposable vector 𝒙=⊗n≥1xn with respect to 𝒂. Observe that without any assumption, the equality 𝝅(g)⊗n≥1xn=⊗n≥1πn(g)xn does not make any sense, since (πn⁢(g)⁢xn)n≥1, which is a C0-sequence, may not be equivalent to 𝒂, and thus may not belong to ⊗n≥1𝒂Hn.

Infinite tensor products of unitary representations have already been studied in various contexts (see for instance [4] and the references therein). In [4, Prop. 2.3], the following observation is made: suppose that, for each n≥1, Un is a unitary operator on Hn. Then there exists a unitary operator 𝑼=⊗\gnUn on ⊗n≥1𝒂Hn satisfying

𝑼(⊗n≥1xn)=⊗\gnUxnn

for every decomposable vector 𝒙=⊗n≥1xn with respect to 𝒂 if and only if the series ∑n≥1|1-⟨Un⁢an,an⟩| is convergent (which is equivalent to requiring that the C0-sequence (Un⁢an)n≥1 be equivalent to (an)n≥1, i. e. to the fact that ⊗\gnUann be a decomposable vector with respect to 𝒂). It follows from this result that the formula (22) makes sense in ⊗n≥1𝒂Hn if and only if the series

∑n≥1|1-⟨πn⁢(g)⁢an,an⟩| (23)

is convergent for every g∈G. Under this condition 𝝅(g)=⊗n≥1πn(g) is a unitary operator on ⊗n≥1𝒂Hn for every g∈G, and 𝝅⁢(g⁢h)=𝝅⁢(g)⁢𝝅⁢(h) for every g,h∈G.

If the group G is discrete, this tensor product representation is of course automatically strongly continuous. It is also the case if G is supposed to be locally compact.

Proposition A.1

Suppose that G is locally compact. If the series

∑n≥1|1-⟨πn⁢(g)⁢an,an⟩|

is convergent for every g∈G, then 𝛑=⊗n≥1πn is strongly continuous, and is hence a unitary representation of G on ⊗n≥1𝐚Hn.

{proof}

Since all the spaces Hn, n≥1, are separable, ⊗n≥1𝒂Hn is separable too, and by [7, Lem. A.6.2] it suffices to show that \xymatrix⁢g⁢\ar⁢@⁢|->⁢[r]⁢&⁢⟨𝝅⁢(g)⁢𝝃,𝝃⟩ is a measurable map from G into ℂ for every vector 𝝃∈⊗n≥1𝒂Hn (measurability refers to the Haar measure on G). Since the linear span of the elementary vectors is dense in ⊗n≥1𝒂Hn, standard arguments show that it suffices to prove this for elementary vectors 𝒙=⊗n≥1xn of ⊗n≥1𝒂Hn. Since each map \xymatrix⁢g⁢\ar⁢@⁢|->⁢[r]⁢&⁢⟨πn⁢(g)⁢xn,xn⟩ is continuous on G, it is clear that \xymatrix⁢g⁢\ar⁢@⁢|->⁢[r]⁢&⁢⟨𝝅⁢(g)⁢𝒙,𝒙⟩=∏n≥1⟨πn⁢(g)⁢xn,xn⟩ is measurable on G. In the general case one needs to impose an additional condition on the representations πn and on the vectors an in order that 𝝅 be a strongly continuous representation of G on ⊗n≥1𝒂Hn.

Proposition A.2

Suppose that the series ∑n≥1|1-⟨πn⁢(g)⁢an,an⟩| is convergent for every g∈G and that the function

\xymatrix⁢g⁢\ar⁢@⁢|->⁢[r]⁢&⁢∑n≥1|1-⟨πn⁢(g)⁢an,an⟩|

is continuous on a neighborhood of the identity element e of G. Then 𝛑=⊗n≥1πn is strongly continuous, and is hence a unitary representation of G on ⊗n≥1𝐚Hn.

{proof}

[Proof of Proposition A.2] Since the linear span of the elementary vectors is dense in ⊗n≥1𝒂Hn, and the operators 𝝅⁢(g), g∈G, are unitary, it suffices to prove that the map \xymatrix⁢g⁢\ar⁢@⁢|->⁢[r]⁢&⁢𝝅⁢(g)⁢𝒙 is continuous at e for every elementary vector 𝒙=⊗n≥1xn of norm 1 of ⊗n≥1𝒂Hn. Let N≥1 be such that xn=an for every n>N. We have for every g∈G:

||𝝅⁢(g)⁢𝒙-𝒙||2 =2⁢(1-ℜ⁡e⁢⟨𝝅⁢(g)⁢𝒙,𝒙⟩)=2⁢(1-∏n≥1ℜ⁡e⁢⟨πn⁢(g)⁢xn||xn||,xn||xn||⟩)
since ||𝒙||=∏n≥1||xn||=1. Thus
||𝝅⁢(g)⁢𝒙-𝒙||2 ≤2⁢∑n≥1|1-⟨πn⁢(g)⁢xn||xn||,xn||xn||⟩|
≤2∑n=1N|1-⟨πn(g)xn||xn||,xn||xn||⟩|+2∑n≥1|1-⟨πn(g)an,an⟩|.

Let ε be any positive number. Since the representations π1,…,πN are strongly continuous, and the map \xymatrix⁢g⁢\ar⁢@⁢|->⁢[r]⁢&⁢∑n≥1|1-⟨πn⁢(g)⁢an,an⟩| is continuous at the point e, the quantity ||𝝅⁢(g)⁢𝒙-𝒙||2 is less than ε2 if g lies in a suitable neighborhood of e. This proves the continuity of the map \xymatrix⁢g⁢\ar⁢@⁢|->⁢[r]⁢&⁢𝝅⁢(g)⁢𝒙.

We finish this appendix by giving a sufficient condition for an infinite tensor product representation on a space ⊗n≥1𝒂Hn to be weakly mixing: let, for each n≥1, Hn be a separable Hilbert space, an a vector of Hn with ||an||=1, and πn a unitary representation of G on Hn. We suppose that the assumptions of either Proposition A.1 (when G is locally compact) or Proposition A.2 (in the general case) are satisfied, so that 𝝅=⊗n≥1πn is a unitary representation of G on ⊗n≥1𝒂Hn. Then

Proposition A.3

In the case where

lim¯n→+∞⁢m⁢(|⟨πn⁢(∙)⁢an,an⟩|2)=0,

the representation 𝛑=⊗n≥1πn is weakly mixing.

{proof}

The proof of Proposition A.3 relies on the same idea as that of Proposition A.2: let 𝒙=⊗n≥1xn and 𝒚=⊗n≥1yn be two elementary vectors in ⊗n≥1𝒂Hn with ||𝒙||=||𝒚||=1. We have

|⟨𝝅⁢(g)⁢𝒙,𝒚⟩|2 =∏k≥1|⟨πk⁢(g)⁢xk||xk||,yk||yk||⟩|2≤|⟨πn⁢(g)⁢xn||xn||,yn||yn||⟩|2
for every n≥1 and every g∈G. But
|⟨πn⁢(g)⁢xn||xn||,yn||yn||⟩| ≤|⟨πn(g)an,an⟩|+||xn||xn||-an||+||yn||yn||-an||.
Squaring and taking the mean on both sides we obtain that
m⁢(|⟨𝝅⁢(∙)⁢𝒙,𝒚⟩|2) ≤4⁢m⁢(|⟨πn⁢(∙)⁢an,an⟩|2)+4⁢||xn||xn||-an||2+4⁢||yn||yn||-an||2

for every n≥1. Since lim¯n→+∞⁢m⁢(|⟨πn⁢(∙)⁢an,an⟩|2)=0 and the two other terms are equal to zero for n sufficiently large, m⁢(|⟨𝝅⁢(∙)⁢𝒙,𝒚⟩|2)=0. Weak mixing of 𝝅 now follows from standard density arguments.
